revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Refimprove|article|date=March 2011}} '''Nicolas Economou''' ({{lang-gr|Νικόλας Οικονόμου}}; 11 August 1953 – 29 December 1993) was a Cypriot composer and pianist born in [[Nicosia]], Cyprus.
A precociously gifted pianist, Economou came to international attention at the 1969 [[International Tchaikovsky Competition|Tchaikovsky Competition]] when he was 16. After studying at the [[Moscow Conservatory|Tchaikovsky Conservatory]] in Moscow he eventually moved via [[Düsseldorf]] to [[Munich]]. From his base there he established himself throughout Europe as a concert pianist, composer, arranger, conductor and organiser of music festivals. In December 1993 Economou was killed in an automobile accident in Cyprus while driving at night in thick fog.
==Precocious talent== Nicolas Economou was the first child of his family. His parents, who loved classical music, decided to expose him to music as a creative outlet rather than a career. At the age of five, he started taking piano lessons and he soon revealed his extraordinary talent by improvising on the piano and composing short pieces of music. When [[Solon Michaelides]], the celebrated Cypriot composer, conductor, musicologist and friend of the family heard him play for the first time, when Economou was not yet seven years old, he declared: "This child is a blessing to his parents, Cyprus, and the World". On his advice, Economou's musical training was undertaken by George Arvanitakis.
The turning point in Economou's life came at the age of ten. It had to be decided whether he would eventually take up music as a career. Again Solon Michaelides, who was following Economou's progress, suggested that his musical education should be continued outside Cyprus where he would have greater opportunities. In September 1964, after an audition, he was accepted at the [[Moscow Conservatory|Special School of Music of the Tchaikovsky Conservatory]] in Moscow, a preparatory school for youngsters to enter the Conservatory. In December of that year, in [[Athens]], he won the "Keti Papaioannou" Panhellenic Competition for young musicians up to the age of seventeen. Events themselves were now forming the course of Economou's life. The following year at the age of twelve, far away from his family and culture, he began his musical studies in Moscow.
After three years of studies, his piano teacher suggested that he should enter the [[International Tchaikovsky Competition|Tchaikovsky Competition]], a world-renowned international music competition. After a year of preparation and at the age of sixteen, he participated in the competition, gaining favourable reviews from the press, radio and television. A year later, he was admitted to the Tchaikovsky Conservatory itself. Leaving Moscow in 1972, he moved to [[Düsseldorf]], before settling in [[Munich]], Germany.
==Pianist== As a performer, he appeared in Europe, the USA and Canada as well as the USSR, Japan, Iceland, and Israel. He performed solo, and with orchestras and other famous performers and composers like [[Martha Argerich]], [[Rodion Shchedrin]], [[Sviatoslav Richter]], [[Michel Beroff]], [[Chick Corea]] and others. As well as performing in concert with Martha Argerich and Chick Corea, he also recorded with them. The record with Chick Corea, entitled ''On Two Pianos'', was the result of a series of concerts in Germany in 1981/82 during which the two musicians interacted with each other by improvising in their own style. He also released two other solo albums.
The Nicolas Economou Foundation posthumously published seven CDs under the series title ''L'Art de Nicolas Economou'', compiling hours of recordings that Economou left behind.
==Composer== Economou studied composition with [[Vladislav Zolotaryov]] and [[Wilhelm Killmayer]]. He wrote music for piano, for small ensembles, symphonic music and film music. Many of his compositions have themes and rhythms from Cyprus and the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]]. Some of his compositions are: ''Children Studies'', ''Sonata for Chick'' (dedicated to Chick Corea) for piano, ''Cyprus Picture'' and ''Cyprus Dances'' for an [[musical ensemble|ensemble]] of eight players. He wrote the soundtracks for twelve films including ''[[Rosa Luxemburg (film)|Rosa Luxemburg]]'' and ''[[Marianne and Juliane|Die bleierne Zeit]]'', both by [[Margarethe von Trotta]].
Economou also arranged [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]]'s ''[[The Nutcracker|The Nutcracker Suite]]'' (originally written for orchestra) for two pianos, dedicated to his daughter and Martha Argerich's daughter. Performers and critics alike have praised this arrangement, since all the musical colours portrayed by the orchestra are very well conveyed by two pianos. Economou also arranged Vivaldi's ''[[The Four Seasons (Vivaldi)|The Four Seasons]]'' for four pianos.
==Conductor and organiser== In 1978, with the collaboration of the City of Munich, Economou organised a "Cyprus Week" in Munich, with artists from Cyprus including actors, musicians, painters, sculptors and the late shadow performer, Paphios. He was also the founder of the "Solisten Ensemble" in Munich with which he performed some of his compositions and those of other composers. He was the co-founder of the well-established [[Münchner Klaviersommer]] (Munich Piano Summer). In February 1992 he organised in [[Venice]] the first of a series of piano festivals he intended to establish in Europe with the title "Pianisti non-Solo".
As a conductor he directed the distinguished [[Moscow Chamber Orchestra]], the [[Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra|Bavarian Symphony Orchestra]], Germany's Youth Orchestra and the La Fenice Opera Orchestra of Venice.
==Recognition and awards== In acknowledgement of his services and contribution to culture and the arts in general, Economou was honoured on various occasions by several bodies. * The city of Munich honoured him in 1979 for his contribution to the arts, as a composer and interpreter of classical and modern music, with the award for "Best Interpreter of the Year". * In 1983, the Bavarian TV produced a television portrait of Economou, more than an hour in duration, in which he is shown in all facets of his creative life. The film, called ''Kreisleriana'' (after the [[Kreisleriana|work for piano]] by Schumann), was directed by Klaus Voswinkel. * Since 1988, a seat bearing his name has stood in the [[Prinzregententheater]] of the City of Munich, next to seats of other prominent artists. * In Cyprus he was honoured with the 1991 "Tefkros Anthias and Theodosis Pierides Award". * Because of his outstanding contribution to music, he was accepted in 1992 into one of Europe's prominent societies, the Academia Scientiarum et Artium Europaea (The [[European Academy of Sciences and Arts]]), members of which are [[Nobel prize winners]], politicians, artists, church dignitaries and others.
==Character== Economou was a thinker and expressed many of this thoughts and ideas in literary work, poetry and prose. He was a citizen of the World and refused to accept borders, either in the geographical sense, in artistic expression or ideas.
He had many well-known friends, not only musicians but also persons coming from a variety of intellectual backgrounds. Among them as the late philosopher and playwright [[Friedrich Dürrenmatt]], with whom he had a special bond. Others include [[Arthur Miller]] and his family, [[Rodion Shchedrin]] and the legendary Maja Plisestkaya, [[Maximilian]] and [[Maria Schell]], [[Volker Schlondorff]] and [[Margarethe von Trotta]]. In [[Greece]] he had close ties with the late Solon Michaelides and [[Manos Hadjidakis]].
Even though he spent almost all of his life far away from his birthplace, deep inside he remained a Cypriot with all the characteristics of the Mediterranean people. He never lost touch with the island and during his visits to Cyprus he used to mix with all kinds of people, regardless of their background. He greatly enjoyed discussing politics and would eagerly prompt discussions on life and philosophical issues. He was always frank and direct and had no inhibitions in expressing an opinion, and for this he was very much respected.
==Personal life== Nicolas Economou is the father of [[Semeli Economou]] from his first marriage to Greek-American born Maritsa Tsirigos.
==Sources== *http://www.nicolaseconomou.com including [http://www.nicolaseconomou.com/recordings.htm discography] and [http://www.nicolaseconomou.com/work.htm list of compositions] *[http://www.nefcy.com The Nicolas Economou Foundation] including [https://web.archive.org/web/20060429165226/http://www.nefcy.com/Biography.htm biography]
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090917001408/http://www.classicaltv.com/search-tag/nicolas-economou Nicolas Economou on ClassicalTV] *{{IMDb name|0248786}}
{{Authority control}}

{{excessive detail | date=June 2015}} '''Nintendo Campus Challenge''' was a video game competition sponsored by [[Nintendo]] and held at nearly 60 college campuses and other events throughout the United States, including a Canadian Tour. There were two Campus Challenge events, one in [[Nintendo Campus Challenge 1991|1991]] and another in [[Nintendo Campus Challenge 1992|1992]]. ==1991 games== [[File:Campus-challenge-1991.jpg|thumb|right|''Nintendo Campus Challenge 1991'' Cartridge]] Like [[Nintendo World Championships]], the official event gave each player 6 minutes and 21 seconds to play in the contest, but there are three different minigames. The first minigame of the competition is ''[[Super Mario Bros. 3]]'', where players must collect 25 coins. The next minigame is a version of [[Pin*Bot (video game)|''Pin*Bot'']]'','' where players must get 100,000 points. The final minigame is [[Dr. Mario (video game)|''Dr. Mario'']], which lasts until the time expires. Once time expires, a player's score is totaled using the following formula: *''Super Mario Bros. 3'' score times 10 *+ ''PinBot'' score *+ ''Dr. Mario'' score times 100 The following advertisement was printed in Game Players Strategy Guide to Nintendo Games Vol. 4, issue #5: ''"Ok, you should really be studying for that calculus test next week. And there's a paper due in English Lit. But who cares? The Nintendo Camps Challenge is coming! Nintendo of America is following up its hugely successful Nintendo World Champions with its first Nintendo Campus Challenge. During the next year, competitions will be held at 50 universities and popular spring break gatherings throughout the U.S. One lucky student will become the 'college valedictorian of videogames.' Contestants will play a special combination of three Nintendo games - Dr. Mario, Rad Racer, and Super Mario Bros. 3. There are categories for both men and women, and all finalists receive round-trip airfare to the January 1992 championship. Prizes include new cars and cash scholarships. Meanwhile, don't let those grades slide too badly."'' {{Cite web|url = http://www.neswarpzone.com/campus.html|title = Nintendo Campus Challenge|date = |accessdate = 2014-10-28|website = NESWarpZone.com|publisher = |last = |first = }} ''[[Rad Racer]]'' was not used in the final version of the competition cartridge, as it had previously appeared on the [[Nintendo World Championships]] cartridge and that both games used a different mapper chip than what the 1991 Nintendo Campus Challenge uses. ==1991 cartridge== {{see also|Video game collecting}} There is only one known original copy of the 1991 Campus Challenge cartridge known to exist. The game was found by a [[Video game collecting|video game collector]], Rob Walters, at a garage sale in New York {{cite web | title = Greatest Video Game Garage Sale | publisher = VGPC.com | url = http://blog.videogamepricecharts.com/2009/07/greatest-video-game-garage-sale-ever.html | accessdate = 2009-08-09 }} in 2006. The game sold for $14,000 in July 2009 to collector JJ Hendricks.{{cite web | title = Nintendo Campus Challenge 1991 Price History | publisher = VGPC.com | url = http://www.videogamepricecharts.com/game/nes/nintendo-campus-challenge-1991 | accessdate = 2009-08-09 }} After 3 months, Hendricks resold the game on eBay for $20,100.{{Cite web|url = http://www.racketboy.com/journal/game-collecting/nes1991-nintendo-campus-challenge-cartridge|title = Behind the Sale: 1991 Nintendo Campus Challenge Cartridge|date = 2009-10-22|accessdate = 2014-10-28|website = RacketBoy.com|publisher = |last = |first = }} ==1991 event structure== The [[Nintendo Campus Challenge 1991]] was held at 58 college campuses and [[spring break]] locations. The event consisted of three stages. The main stage had the competition on 12 different game stations. The second stage was [[Nintendo Entertainment System]] systems with various games while the third stage had [[Game Boy]] systems. Attendees at the events could play as many times as they wanted and the highest score at the end of the day was announced the winner. The winner from each location was flown to [[Disney World]] in [[Orlando]], [[Florida]] over [[New Year]]'s weekend in January 1992.{{cite web | title = Campus Challenge Video | publisher = Youtube.com | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iQuZb90i6WY | accessdate = 2017-10-26 }} All the competitors played in the first round followed by a second round with the six highest scoring players only. The final round was a head-to-head match between Steven Lucas and Matt Sekelsky. Steven Lucas won with a score of 2,394,130.{{cite web | title = Campus Challenge Winner Video | publisher = Youtube.com | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XGjGrkavHYA | accessdate = 2017-10-26 }} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! School ! City |- | 11/29/1990 | [[Louisiana State University]] | Baton Rouge |- | [tel:12/3/1990 12/3/1990] | [[Texas A&M University]] | College Station |- | [tel:12/6/1990 12/6/1990] | [[University of Oklahoma]] | Norman |- | 1/10/1991 | [[Consumer Electronics Show]] | Las Vegas |- | 1/15/1991 | [[California Polytechnic State University]] (Cal Poly) | San Luis Obispo |- | 1/17/1991 | [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] | Santa Barbara |- | 1/21/1991 | [[University of California, Los Angeles]] | [[Los Angeles]] |- | 1/24/1991 | [[University of Southern California]] | Los Angeles |- | 1/28/1991 | [[California State University, Long Beach]] | Long Beach |- | 1/31/1991 | [[University of California, Irvine]] | Irvine |- | 2/4/1991 | [[California State University, Fullerton]] | [[Fullerton, California|Fullerton]] |- | 2/7/1991 | [[San Diego State University]] | [[San Diego]] |- | 2/11/1991 | [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] | [[Las Vegas]] |- | 2/14/1991 | [[Arizona State University]] | Tempe |- | 2/18/1991 | [[University of Arizona]] | Tucson |- | 2/21/1991 | [[University of New Mexico]] | Albuquerque |- | 2/25/1991 | [[Texas Tech University]] | Lubbock |- | 2/28/1991 | [[University of Texas at Arlington]] | Arlington |- | 3/4/1991 | [[University of Texas at Austin]] | Austin |- | 3/7/1991 | [[University of Houston]] | Houston |- | 3/11/1991 | Spring Break event | [[South Padre Island]] |- | 3/19/1991 | Spring Break event | Kenny Dedic - [[Daytona Beach]] |- | 3/25/1991 | Spring Break event | [[Daytona Beach]] |- | 4/4/1991 | [[University of Georgia]] | Athens |- | 4/8/1991 | [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] | Atlanta |- | 4/11/1991 | [[Auburn University]] | Auburn |- | 4/15/1991 | [[University of Alabama]] | [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]] |- | 4/18/1991 | [[University of Tennessee at Knoxville]] | [[Knoxville]] |- | 4/22/1991 | [[Ohio State University]] | Columbus |- | 4/24/1991 | Chevy Open House | [[General Motors Technical Center]]
[[Warren, Michigan]] |- | 4/25/1991 | [[University of Michigan]] | [[Ann Arbor]] |- | 4/29/1991 | [[Indiana University]] | Bloomington |- | 5/2/1991 | [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] | Madison |- | 5/6/1991 | [[University of Minnesota]] | [[Minneapolis]] |- | 5/9/1991 | [[Northwestern University]] | [[Evanston, Illinois|Evanston]] |- | 8/2/1991 | [[Ohio State Fair]] | [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]] |- | 8/15/1991 | [[Illinois State Fair]] | Springfield |- | 8/22/1991-9/20/1991 | Canada Tour | [[Canada]] |- | 9/23/1991 | [[University at Albany]] | Albany |- | 9/26/1991 | [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]] | Amherst |- | 9/30/1991 | [[Boston University]] | [[Boston]] |- | [tel:10/3/1991 10/3/1991] | [[University of Rhode Island]] | Kingston |- | [tel:10/7/1991 10/7/1991] | [[New York University]] | [[New York City]] |- | 10/10/1991 | [[Rutgers University–New Brunswick]] | New Brunswick |- | 10/14/1991 | [[University of Pennsylvania]] | [[Philadelphia]] |- | 10/17/1991 | [[University of Maryland]] | College Park |- | 10/20/1991 | [[West Virginia University]] | Morgantown |- | 10/24/1991 | [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] | Chapel Hill |- | 10/28/1991 | [[Clemson University]] | Clemson |- | 11/11/1991 | [[University of Washington]] | Seattle |- | 11/13/1991 | Nintendo Open House | Seattle |- | 11/18/1991 | [[University of Oregon]] | Eugene |- | 11/27/1991 | [[California State University, Sacramento]] | Sacramento |- | [tel:12/2/1991 12/2/1991] | [[University of California, Berkeley]] | Berkeley |- | [tel:12/5/1991 12/5/1991] | [[Stanford University]] | Stanford |- | [tel:12/9/1991 12/9/1991] | [[San Jose State University]] | [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] |- | 1/4/1992 | [[Walt Disney World]] | [[Orlando]] |- |} ==1992 games== [[File:Campus-challenge-1992.jpg|thumb|right|''Nintendo Campus Challenge 1992'' Cartridge]] The SNES Campus Challenge cart has an unusual shape, with the PCB board parallel to the SNES. The cart has four ROM chips, presumably three for each game plus the additional one to link them all together. It also has the [[List of Super NES enhancement chips|DSP-1]] chip, which is used in ''[[Pilotwings]]''. There is a set of eight switches, which were likely used to change the settings in the game, although they seemed to have no effect when changed. A phone jack is present, likely to relay the scores to a Nintendo server to determine the grand prize winner. The rules are the same as the 1991 version, except with three SNES minigames. The first minigame of the competition is ''[[Super Mario World]]'', where players must collect 50 coins (very similar to Nintendo World Championships' first minigame, ''[[Super Mario Bros.]]''). The second game is a version of ''[[F-Zero]],'' where players must complete two laps. The final minigame is ''Pilotwings,'' where players must land on two targets successfully. Once time expires, a player's score is totaled using the following formula:{{cite web | title = Nintendo Campus Challenge | publisher = MarioWiki.com | url = http://www.mariowiki.com/Nintendo_Campus_Challenge | accessdate = 2009-07-13 }} *''Super Mario World'' score *+ ''F-Zero'' score times 100 *+ ''Pilotwings'' score times 10,000 == 1992 cartridge == There are reportedly three cartridges in existence,{{Cite web|url = http://kotaku.com/5868520/and-now-the-25000-super-nintendo-cartridge|title = And Now, the $25,000 Super Nintendo Cartridge|date = 2011-12-15|accessdate = 2014-10-28|website = Kotaku.com|publisher = |last = |first = }} but only two known are known. One was found at the same [[New York City]] garage sale by Rob Walters as the 1991 cartridge. The cartridge is owned by a video game collector named Rick Bruns.{{cite web | title = Nintendo 1992 Campus Challenge | publisher = SNESMaps.com | url = http://snesmaps.com/maps/1992Challenge/1992Challenge.html | accessdate = 2009-08-10 }} The second one was found in an attic of a former employee of a company who did projects for Nintendo. Nintendo sent the cartridge to the company along with some systems and other games. ==1992 event structure== The 1992 "Nintendo Campus Challenge" competition was held at 35 college campuses throughout the US, including Central Michigan University, Arizona State University, and Texas A&M University. The winner at each location won a [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]] Super Set with two controllers and a ''Super Mario World'' game cartridge, along with individual copies of '' F-Zero'', and ''Pilotwings''. Consolation prizes of $100, $75, and $50 were awarded to second, third, and fourth place contestants. The winner of the whole US competition won $10,000. In addition, all the winners were put into a draw to win prizes of $5,000.{{Cite web|url = http://www.snescentral.com/article.php?id=0790|title = Nintendo Campus Challenge|date = |accessdate = 2014-10-28|website = SNESCentral.com|publisher = |last = |first = }} Along with the competition cartridge, Nintendo sent previews for new games, including ''[[Contra III: The Alien Wars]]'', [[Rival Turf!|''Rival Turf'']],'' [[The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past]]'', ''[[The Addams Family (video game)|The Addams Family]]'', and ''[[Super Scope 6]]''.{{Cite web|url = https://groups.google.com/forum/?hl=en#!topic/rec.games.video/MDmDn6main0|title = Nintendo Campus Challenge|date = 1991-04-14|accessdate = 2014-10-28|website = Usenet.com|publisher = |last = |first = }} Similar competitions were held in Europe and Japan in 1992. The winner of the US competition, Jeff Hanson, won against the winner of the Japanese competition, Yuichi Suyama, and became the World Champion at the 1993 [[Consumer Electronics Show]].{{Cite book|title = Greatest Moments in Video Game History|last = Weston|first = D.B.|publisher = DB Weston|date = 2012-08-07|isbn = 9781301174140|location = |pages = 62}} ==See also== *[[Nintendo World Championships]] *[[Nintendo PowerFest '94]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Nintendo Company}} [[Category:1991 in American sports]] [[Category:Nintendo events]] [[Category:ESports competitions in the United States]] [[Category:ESports in Canada]]

revision.comment: Repairing links to disambiguation pages - [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|You can help!]]
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} In [[film studies|film]], [[diegesis]] refers to the story world, and the events that occur within it. Thus, non-diegesis are things which occur outside the story-world.
A '''non-diegetic insert''' is a film technique that combines a shot or a series of shots cut into a sequence, showing objects represented as being outside the space of the narrative. Put more simply, a non-diegetic insert is a scene that is outside the story world which is "inserted" into the story world. Diegetic could also refer to sound in media or film studies.
==Examples== * Three images shown during the disastrous opening night of the play in ''[[The Band Wagon]]'', as a metaphor to highlight how much of a flop the show is. * Sky sequences shown in [[Gus Van Sant]]'s [[Elephant (2003 film)|''Elephant'']]. *Most famously in ''[[The Great Train Robbery (1903 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'' a bandit, either following the character's death or before the narrative began, shot his gun directly at the audience. * Starting scene of Charlie Chaplin's film [[Modern_Times_(film)|Modern Times]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Non-Diegetic Insert}} [[Category:Film and video terminology]]
{{Film-term-stub}}

revision.comment: added [[Category:Performing arts in Slovenia]]; removed {{uncategorized}} using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Performing arts of Slovenia''' are shaped by a number of Slovenian actors and actresses, dancers, theatre directors, and theatre managers. Several professional and a number of amateur [[Community theatre|community]] theatres operate on the [[Repertory theatre|repertory]] system in Slovenia.
==The national theatres== There are four national theatres in Slovenia that include the [[Ljubljana National Drama Theatre]] and [[Slovene National Theatre Opera and Ballet Company]], both located in [[Ljubljana]]; the [[Maribor National Drama Theatre]], located in [[Maribor]]; and [[Slovenian Littoral National Theatre]], located in [[Nova Gorica]].
==Other professional theatres== Founded in 1949, [[Ljubljana City Theatre]] is the second largest drama theatre in Slovenia. Founded in 1955 as the first professional theater for children and youth in Slovenia was the [[Slovenian Youth Theatre]]. Established in 1948, the [[Ljubljana Puppet Theatre]], located in Ljubljana, is a puppet [[repertory theatre]].<ref>[http://www.culture.si/en/Ljubljana_Puppet_Theatre Ljubljana Puppet Theatre], on the culture.si website</ref>
Established in 2011, the [[Koper Theatre]], located in [[Koper]], is the second youngest professional theatre in Slovenia.<ref>[http://www.gledalisce-koper.si/index.php?page=static&item=79 History of the Koper Theatre], the theatre official website</ref>
Other theatres include [[Glej Theatre]].<ref>[http://www.culture.si/en/Glej_Theatre Glej Theatre], on the culture.si website</ref>
==See also== *[[Music of Slovenia]] *[[Art of Slovenia]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Slovenia-hist-stub}}
[[Category:Performing arts in Slovenia]]

page.title: Persona and reception of Roman Reigns

revision.text:
[[File:Reigns March 2018.jpg|thumb|175px|[[Roman Reigns]] in March 2018]] The '''persona and reception of Roman Reigns''' refers to the ascendency of American [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] [[Roman Reigns]] (Leati Joseph Anoaʻi) within [[WWE]], which has divided critical and public opinion.
Reigns debuted on the [[WWE]] main roster in November 2012 (having performed in [[Florida Championship Wrestling|its developmental system]] since 2010) as part of [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#S|stable]] [[The Shield (professional wrestling)|The Shield]] and was well-received by fans and critics. Support began to dwindle upon Reigns's transition to a [[Face (professional wrestling)|heroic]] [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#M|main event]] singles act in 2014, largely due to his perceived forced [[Push (professional wrestling)|push]]. This would manifest itself with Reigns main eventing consecutive [[WrestleMania|WrestleManias]] (WWE's premier annual [[List of WWE pay-per-view events|pay-per-view event]]) facing [[Brock Lesnar]] in a [[professional wrestling match types#Singles matches|singles]] turned [[professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches|triple threat match]] due to [[Seth Rollins]]’ [[Money in the Bank (2014)|Money in the Bank cash-in]] for the [[WWE Championship|WWE World Heavyweight Championship]] at [[WrestleMania 31]], [[Triple H]] in a singles match for the WWE World Heavyweight Championship at [[WrestleMania 32]], [[The Undertaker]] in a [[professional wrestling match types#No Holds Barred|No Holds Barred match]] at [[WrestleMania 33]] and Brock Lesnar for the second time one-on-one in a singles match for the [[WWE Universal Championship]] at [[WrestleMania 34]] while being booed in all four main events.<ref>{{cite web|last=Newby|first=Jake|title=WWE needs to finally do something different with Pensacola's Roman Reigns|url=https://www.pnj.com/story/news/local/2018/04/09/wwe-needs-finally-do-something-different-pensacolas-roman-reigns/499541002/|work=[[Pensacola News Journal]]|accessdate=23 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180423232925/https://www.pnj.com/story/news/local/2018/04/09/wwe-needs-finally-do-something-different-pensacolas-roman-reigns/499541002/|archive-date=23 April 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He has also won the WWE World Heavyweight Championship three times, having a "mixed, at best" crowd reaction on his first world title win, being cheered for his second and being completely booed for his third, but cheered for his first WWE Universal Championship win at [[SummerSlam (2018)|SummerSlam]] in August 2018.
Wrestling journalists have offered both praise and criticism for Reigns, noting both his talent and WWE's apparent attempts to conceal fan hostility towards him. David Shoemaker of ''[[Grantland]]'' wrote in 2016 that Reigns was the company's "most despised wrestler" in over 25 years.<ref name="shoemaker"/> Fans have taken issue with Reigns over various reasons: his perceived special treatment, real-life demeanor, wrestling moveset, speaking skills and character presentation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Keller|first1=Wade|title=Coach telling fans they're sheep if they boo Reigns is not doing Reigns any favors|url=https://www.pwtorch.com/site/2018/03/01/kellers-take-coach-telling-fans-theyre-sheep-boo-reigns-not-reigns-favors/|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=March 25, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180325111514/https://www.pwtorch.com/site/2018/03/01/kellers-take-coach-telling-fans-theyre-sheep-boo-reigns-not-reigns-favors/|archive-date=March 25, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> After Reigns was [[Suspension (punishment)|suspended]] for drug use, [[Yahoo! Sports]] pondered whether he is "the biggest failure in professional wrestling history".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://uk.sports.yahoo.com/news/roman-reigns-the-biggest-failure-in-professional-045403008.html|title=WWE: Roman Reigns - the biggest failure in professional wrestling history?|last=Zheng|first=Sihan|date=July 15, 2016|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|accessdate=February 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211235805/https://uk.sports.yahoo.com/news/roman-reigns-the-biggest-failure-in-professional-045403008.html|archive-date=February 11, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2016, Reigns was voted the [[List of Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Most Overrated|Most Overrated]] by ''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]'' readers<ref name="WON16">{{cite journal|last=Meltzer|first=Dave|authorlink=Dave Meltzer|title=March 6, 2017 Wrestling Observer Newsletter: 2016 Awards issue, talent departing TNA, more|url=http://members.f4wonline.com/wrestling-observer-newsletter/march-6-2017-wrestling-observer-newsletter-2016-awards-issue-talent|journal=[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]|location=[[Campbell, California]]|issn=1083-9593|page=11|access-date=March 19, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170315110955/http://members.f4wonline.com/wrestling-observer-newsletter/march-6-2017-wrestling-observer-newsletter-2016-awards-issue-talent|archive-date=March 15, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> as well as the [[List of Pro Wrestling Illustrated awards#Most Hated Wrestler of the Year|Most Hated Wrestler of the Year]] by ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]'' readers, a first for a heroic character since the award was devised in 1972.<ref name="most hated">{{cite 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="PWIhistory">{{cite web|title=PWI Achievement Award Winners|url=http://www.pwi-online.com/pages/PWIawards.html|website=Pro Wrestling Illustrated|accessdate=March 5, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160121172943/http://www.pwi-online.com/pages/PWIawards.html|archive-date=January 21, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Into 2017, WWE continued trying to establish Reigns as a megastar despite audience rejection.<ref name=bildrumble17>{{cite web|last1=Ahlig|first1=Enrico|title=Fans sauer nach Wrestling-Schlacht|url=http://www.bild.de/unterhaltung/leute/wrestling/fans-sauer-nach-wrestling-schlacht-royal-rumble-50016954.bild.html|work=[[Bild]]|accessdate=30 January 2017|language=German|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170130124156/http://www.bild.de/unterhaltung/leute/wrestling/fans-sauer-nach-wrestling-schlacht-royal-rumble-50016954.bild.html|archive-date=30 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ''[[Pro Wrestling Torch]]'' critics, including editor [[Wade Keller]], have said that company chairman [[Vince McMahon]] is engaged in a "war on fans".<ref>{{cite episode|title=WWE Raw post-game show hosted by Wade Keller|series=[[Wade Keller#Pro Wrestling Torch|Pro Wrestling Torch Livecast]]|network=[[BlogTalkRadio]]|date=January 30, 2017|minutes=c. 54 (commercials vary between locations)|quote=As Todd Martin, ''[Pro Wrestling] Torch'' VIP audio analyst says, it's a 'war on fans'. And Vince McMahon has a war on fans right now: he's not going with the flow – he's fighting it}}.</ref>
Anoaʻi himself has suggested that there is "possible jealousy" from fans over his "major success",<ref name=jealousy/> mocked those who question if he deserves his fictional role,<ref name=deserves/> discounted critiques from anyone who "weren't wrestlers"<ref name=CraveHaters/> and declared that he will not change to appease his critics.<ref name=change/> To remedy the negative reception, Anoa'i has stated that he will "continue to show up" and that his and WWE's approach is for him to "go out there and work hard".<ref name=sunsport18/> Anoa'i's childhood idol [[Bret Hart]] stated that he believes WWE themselves have "ruined" the Reigns character by utilizing bad storytelling and poor writing and blames the company's leaders primarily for Anoa'i failing to reach his potential.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/wwe-s-roman-reigns-ready-to-prove-his-critics-wrong-at-wrestlemania-31-210550571.html|title=WWE's Roman Reigns' real story is better than his fake one|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=March 25, 2015|accessdate=April 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>https://411mania.com/wrestling/bret-hart-says-roman-reigns-is-a-victim-of-bad-booking/</ref><ref>https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/bret-hitman-hart-says-roman-reigns-has-got-potential-blames-wwe-not-getting-over-him-1557210</ref>
== Wrestling persona == === Initial reception (2012–2014) === [[File:The Shield at the post-WrestleMania Raw in 2014.jpg|thumb|Reigns as a member of [[The Shield (professional wrestling)|The Shield]] in April 2014]] While in [[NXT (WWE brand)|NXT]] (the new developmental system) during 2012, Reigns' character was described as a "businessman" who was "always dressed to impress" and viewed himself as "the most valuable commodity in WWE".<ref name="NXTprofile">{{cite web|url=http://www.fcwwrestling.info/Roster/Roman-Leakee.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125105817/http://www.fcwwrestling.info/Roster/Roman-Reigns.html|title=Roman Reigns – NXT Profile|archivedate=November 25, 2012|accessdate=December 16, 2015|publisher=NXT Wrestling}}</ref>
Reigns debuted to the main roster as part of [[The Shield (professional wrestling)|The Shield]] in November 18, 2012 at [[Survivor Series (2012)|Survivor Series]]. After transferring to WWE's main roster, his character was changed to the "powerhouse" and "heavy hitter" of The Shield, as well as an "exceptional athlete".<ref>{{cite web|title=Dean Ambrose, Seth Rollins and Roman Reigns: Who are they and why did they help CM Punk|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/2012/dean-ambrose-seth-rollins-and-roman-reigns-who-are-they-and-why-did-they-help-punk-26069706/page-2|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=December 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107051036/http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/2012/dean-ambrose-seth-rollins-and-roman-reigns-who-are-they-and-why-did-they-help-punk-26069706/page-2|archive-date=January 7, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Noted as the least talkative of The Shield members,<ref>{{cite web|last1=McKinley|first1=Shane|title=Absurdity Of It All: Everyone This Week: How Miz Acquired Flair's Figure-Four, Why Reigns Remains Silent, Taz Ruins Endorsement Deal, Absurd Mania Picks, And...I Confess To Oprah|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/absurityofitall/article_67998.shtml|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=December 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123140924/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/absurityofitall/article_67998.shtml|archive-date=January 23, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Reigns' character was tweaked from "the quiet muscle" to being an "ultra-confident" source of leadership with "quiet strength" in mid-2013.<ref name=changeevident>{{cite web|title=WWE News: Changes to The Shield evident in post-loss promo (w/Analysis of the group vs. individuals)|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_71622.shtml|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=December 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229221437/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_71622.shtml|archive-date=December 29, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[CM Punk]] alleged in an interview that he was constantly reminded to make Reigns look "really, really strong" despite The Shield being booked to lose to Punk at the 2013 [[TLC: Tables, Ladders & Chairs (2013)|TLC: Tables, Ladders & Chairs]] event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Punk News: When did C.M. Punk know it was time for him to leave WWE?, Punk captures the moment, shares infamous TLC story, identifies Roman Reigns as the "chosen one|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_82106.shtml|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=December 5, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141207191425/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_82106.shtml|archive-date=December 7, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2013, Reigns was voted the [[List of Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Most Improved|Most Improved]] by ''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]'' readers.<ref name="WON13">{{cite journal|last=Meltzer|first=Dave|authorlink=Dave Meltzer|date=January 27, 2014|title=Jan 27 2014 Wrestling Observer Newsletter: 2013 Annual awards issue, best in the world in numerous categories, plus all the news in pro-wrestling and MMA over the past week and more|journal=[[Dave Meltzer#Wrestling Observer Newsletter|Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]|location=[[Campbell, California]]|issn=1083-9593|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/component/content/article/110-wrestling-observer-newsletter/35067-jan-27-2014-wrestling-observer-newsletter-2013-annual-awards-issue-best-in-the-world-in-numerous-categories-plus-all-the-news-in-pro-wrestling-and-mma-over-the-past-week-and-more|pages=1–37}}</ref>
During the [[Royal Rumble (2014)|2014 Royal Rumble]] [[Royal Rumble#Match|match]] on January 26, the live crowd cheered for Reigns over eventual winner [[Dave Bautista|Batista]] despite Reigns being a [[Heel (professional wrestling)|villain]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|title=WWE Royal Rumble PPV results 1/26 (Hour 3): Royal Rumble vs. The Crowd main event match|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wweppvs/article_75919.shtml|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=January 28, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201005455/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wweppvs/article_75919.shtml|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=LaBar|first=Justin|title=Royal Rumble's Pittsburgh debut makes memorable weekend|url=http://triblive.com/sports/prowrestling/5486954-74/story|publisher=[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review|TribLive]]|accessdate=January 28, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419152502/http://triblive.com/sports/prowrestling/5486954-74/story|archive-date=April 19, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Anoaʻi later acknowledged the reaction as "a cool situation".<ref name=CraveHaters>{{cite web|last1=Caudill|first1=Joshua|title=Roman Reigns Talks 'Royal Rumble,' Injury Return & Haters|url=http://www.craveonline.com/sports/articles/814477-roman-reigns-talks-royal-rumble-injury-return-haters|publisher=[[CraveOnline]]|accessdate=February 23, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223095433/http://www.craveonline.com/sports/articles/814477-roman-reigns-talks-royal-rumble-injury-return-haters|archive-date=February 23, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In mid-2014, [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]] said he saw great potential in Reigns<ref>{{cite web|title=Thursday's Ask PWTorch staff: Will Cena get booed at his Hall of Fame induction years from now? What has Roman Reigns done to earn future top star status? Was Jericho supposed to become champion 2001? Cena vs. Bryan?|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/askpwtorch/article_77974.shtml|access-date=2014-04-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427080417/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/askpwtorch/article_77974.shtml|archive-date=2014-04-27|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> while David Shoemaker of ''[[Grantland]]'' wrote that Reigns had "mystery and intensity" as well as "superstar written all over him".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shoemaker|first1=David|title=The Pro Wrestling Draft Board|url=http://grantland.com/features/wwe-nfl-draft-masked-man-top-prospects-roman-reigns-bray-wyatt-triple-h/|accessdate=February 24, 2015|publisher=[[Grantland]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224073453/http://grantland.com/features/wwe-nfl-draft-masked-man-top-prospects-roman-reigns-bray-wyatt-triple-h/|archive-date=February 24, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Controversial rise to main event status (2014–2016) === After The Shield disbanded, Reigns (unlike the other former Shield members) retained much of The Shield's aesthetic including ring attire, a remixed version of the group's theme music and ring entrance.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mezzera|first1=Jon|title=6/20 WWE Smackdown Hits & Misses: Ziggler vs. Barrett, Kane vs. Ambrose, MITB Participants Talking and Wrestling|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/hitsandmisses/article_79197.shtml|website=PWTorch.com|accessdate=July 5, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626165908/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/hitsandmisses/article_79197.shtml|archive-date=June 26, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/askpwtorch/article_81083.shtml|title=Ask PWTorch All-Stars 10/05: What will the next WWE era be about? Why does Reigns have the old Shield music and should he? Who is Cena's most likely WrestleMania 31 opponent? Should Spike force the ouster of Dixie? Low Ki-Lay Cool?|website=PWTorch.com|accessdate=January 23, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110163106/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/askpwtorch/article_81083.shtml|archive-date=January 10, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Initially, Roman was one of the most popular stars on the roster with fans. === Character alterations and suspension (2016–2017) === On the ''Raw'' after WrestleMania 32, Reigns declared that he was now not a "bad guy" nor a "good guy", but "The Guy", which supposedly indicated a [[glossary of professional wrestling terms#Tweener|morally ambiguous]] character turn, but this went nowhere.<ref name=theguy>{{cite web|last1=Ferguson|first1=LaToya|title=The vicious cycle of WWE continues with the RAW after WrestleMania|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/vicious-cycle-wwe-continues-raw-after-wrestlemania-234815|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=April 15, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415170218/http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/vicious-cycle-wwe-continues-raw-after-wrestlemania-234815|archive-date=April 15, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In April, ''Pro Wrestling Dot Net'' reported that WWE "went out of their way to use [the charity] [[Make-A-Wish Foundation|Make A Wish]] in hopes of getting [Reigns] over as a good guy".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Powell|first1=Jason|title=04/25 Powell's WWE Raw Live TV Review|url=http://prowrestling.net/site/2016/04/25/0425-powells-wwe-raw-live-tv-review-luke-gallows-and-karl-anderson-vs-the-usos-aj-styles-vs-sheamus-roman-reigns-vs-alberto-del-rio-final-hype-for-wwe-payback/|website=prowrestling.net|accessdate=April 27, 27, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> As soon as broadcasting for [[Payback (2016)|Payback]] on May 1 stopped, Reigns reportedly turned on the crowd, yelling angrily at them.<ref>{{cite web|title=WWE Payback onsite report: Roman Reigns turns on fans after the show|url=http://prowrestling.net/site/2016/05/02/wwe-payback-onsite-report-roman-reigns-turns-on-fans-after-the-show-crowd-not-updated-on-enzo-amores-health/|website=prowrestling.net|accessdate=May 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504142522/http://prowrestling.net/site/2016/05/02/wwe-payback-onsite-report-roman-reigns-turns-on-fans-after-the-show-crowd-not-updated-on-enzo-amores-health/|archive-date=May 4, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Also in May, Dave Meltzer said WWE wanted Reigns as "the guy who does the [[Charity (practice)|charity work]], so he has to be positioned as a babyface" (the heroic character), adding that WWE's "new [[Gimmick (professional wrestling)|gimmick]]" was positioning that people actually "really like" Reigns and only boo because "it's fun to boo him", which Meltzer said was "absolutely not true" in reality.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Alvarez|first1=Bryan|last2=Meltzer|first2=Dave|title=WOR: WWE Payback recap, Lucha Underground, AAA PPV coming, [[File:United States Champion Roman Reigns.jpg|thumb|Reigns as [[WWE United States Championship|United States Champion]] in December 2016]] As soon as Reigns returned from suspension in July and leading into [[SummerSlam (2016)|SummerSlam]], writers from the ''Pro Wrestling Torch Newsletter'' wrote that ''Raw'' was "still the Roman Reigns Show", "with him necessarily closing out the show with the last laugh" (post-SummerSlam, "''Raw'' is Roman" continued).<ref>{{cite web|title=8/8 Raw: First batch of PWTorch writers reviewing Monday’s Raw!|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/site/2016/08/09/instant-reaction-88-raw-first-batch-pwtorch-writers-reviewing-mondays-raw/|website=PWTorch.com|accessdate=August 16, Anoa'i no longer wore the contact lenses, again changing the Reigns' character look.<ref>{{cite web|title=Instant Reaction – 8/22 Raw: Three-Pack of Big Takeways from post-Summerslam Raw|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/site/2016/08/23/instant-reaction-822-raw-three-pack-big-takeways-post-summerslam-raw/|accessdate=September 18, 26, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Although Reigns dropped from world title contention to being [[WWE United States Championship|United States Champion]] in September, he remained unable to connect with fans.<ref name="pwt101916">{{cite episode|title=Mid-Week Flagship w/Wade Keller & Jason Powell (US version)|series=[[Wade Keller#Pro Wrestling Torch|Pro Wrestling Torch Livecast]]|network=[[BlogTalkRadio]]|date=October 19, 2016}}</ref> Nonetheless, calculated efforts to garner crowd support persisted. [[Wade Keller]] of the ''Pro Wrestling Torch'' said that WWE was damaging its product by associating Reigns with "really good" and "popular" performers in a "hapless attempt" to get him over. ''Pro Wrestling Dot Net'' columnist Jason Powell said that McMahon's "obsession" with generating support for Reigns had handicapped Seth Rollins, whom fans wanted to see as a fan favorite in May, but was kept as a villain to oppose the heroic (and thoroughly booed) Reigns until a "horrible" turn into a fan favorite in September.<ref name="pwt101916"/> In November, Fin Martin of ''[[Power Slam]]'' remarked: "Vince [McMahon] has successfully trained or retrained most of his audience to consume what he is serving. Roman Reigns being the exception, of course. It says something that fans will cheer [[Shane McMahon]]'s toe-curlingly naff attempts at pro wrestling in the ring and his entrance dance... yet they won't cheer for Reigns, no matter how heroically he is portrayed".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.powerslamonline.co.uk/updates/275/It-s-your-letters.htm|title=The Mail|last=Martin|first=Fin|date=November 23, 2016|website=[[Power Slam]]|accessdate=March 15, 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170315153820/http://www.powerslamonline.co.uk/updates/275/It-s-your-letters.htm|archivedate=March 15, 2017|df=}}</ref> As a result of his achievements in 2016, despite topping ''Pro Wrestling Illustrated'' (''PWI'') annual ''[[PWI 500]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.profightdb.com/pwi-500/2016.html|title=Pro Wrestling Illustrated (PWI) 500 for 2016|accessdate=September 1, 2016|work=The Internet Wrestling Database|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201231018/http://profightdb.com/pwi-500/2016.html|archive-date=February 1, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> which is mainly about [[kayfabe]] results,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlingillustrated.blogspot.com/2011/08/pwi-500-1-100.html|title=PWI 500: 1–100|date=August 9, 2011|accessdate=August 9, 2011|work=Pro Wrestling Illustrated|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111127112040/http://prowrestlingillustrated.blogspot.com/2011/08/pwi-500-1-100.html|archive-date=November 27, 2011|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Reigns was voted by ''Pro Wrestling Illustrated'' readers as Most Hated Wrestler of the Year, a first for a heroic character since the award was devised in 1972.<ref name="most hated"/><ref name="PWIhistory"/> ''Wrestling Observer Newsletter'' readers instead awarded Reigns the 2016 [[List of Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Most Overrated|Most Overrated]] award.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Meltzer|first=Dave|authorlink=Dave Meltzer|title=March 6, 2017 Wrestling Observer Newsletter: 2016 Awards issue, talent departing TNA, more|url=http://members.f4wonline.com/wrestling-observer-newsletter/march-6-2017-wrestling-observer-newsletter-2016-awards-issue-talent|journal=[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]|location=[[Campbell, 15, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Reigns had finished in second place for Most Overrated in both 2014 and 2015.<ref name="2015WON"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Meltzer|first=Dave|authorlink=Dave Meltzer|date=January 25, 2016|title=January 25, 2016 Wrestling Observer Newsletter: 2015 Observer Awards Issue|journal=[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]|location=[[Campbell, California]]|issn=1083-9593|page=31}}</ref> In January 2017, ''Pro Wrestling Torch'' began their weekly "Monday Night Reigns-o-meter", which monitored his "ability to beat the odds and come out on top".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Colohue|first1=Tom|title=MONDAY NIGHT REIGNS-O-METER #1: Tracking Roman Reigns’s ability to beat the odds and come out on top|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/site/2017/01/10/monday-night-reigns-o-meter-1-tracking-roman-reignss-ability-beat-odds-come-top/|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=January 10, {{quote box|quote=I think it just pushed me. [...] Some people look at that as a negative, not me. [...] X amount of thousands of people are screaming, booing at the top of their lungs, and I'm the center of attention, so I must be doing something right.|source=<small>Anoa'i describing his reaction to being booed, in a [[ESPN]] audio interview released in January 2017<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[ESPN]]|title=ESPN Audio: On Demand: Roman Reigns|url=http://www.espn.com/espnradio/play?id=18544214|accessdate=February 4, 2017|quote=timestamp 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref></small>|align=right|width=30%}} Going into 2017, WWE continued to edit reactions for Reigns, one example being after he lost the United States Championship to [[Chris Jericho]], when an audience member was shown live jumping for joy at the result, but when WWE showed replays of Reigns' loss they showed a clip of the same fan looking unhappy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Roman Reigns WWE Fan Reaction from Raw Loss Gets Edited (Video)|url=http://www.foxsports.com/wwe/story/roman-reigns-wwe-fan-reaction-from-raw-loss-gets-edited-video-011717|publisher=[[Fox Sports]]|accessdate=18 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170124001636/http://www.foxsports.com/wwe/story/roman-reigns-wwe-fan-reaction-from-raw-loss-gets-edited-video-011717|archive-date=24 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Veteran wrestler Stone Cold Steve Austin and ''Pro Wrestling Torch'' editor Wade Keller criticised Reigns' attitude in mainstream interviews, specifically Reigns stating that he "just" worked 9-to-5 before becoming a professional wrestler as well as flaunting his financial prospects within WWE, with Austin saying Reigns has "got to watch" what he says and needs to be "smarter" while Keller saw him as "trying to impress the people interviewing him" and "not thinking about the fans who are paying the money for the seats".<ref>{{cite episode|title=Interview Thursday: Keller w/Steve Austin|series=Pro Wrestling Torch Livecast|network=[[BlogTalkRadio]]|date=January 26, 2017}}</ref> Keller also scolded Reigns and WWE for publicly claiming they are happy with any crowd reaction for Reigns, whether positive or negative, describing such statements as "insincere" and "[[Spin (propaganda)|spin]]" since they "turn the volume down; they seek out fans who are cheering him; they doctor footage to make it seem like fans are cheering him when they're not... they manipulate in every way that they can to make it seem like he's not getting a negative reaction".<ref>{{cite episode|title=Mid-Week Flagship w/Wade Keller & Pat McNeill|series=Pro Wrestling Torch Livecast|network=[[BlogTalkRadio]]|date=January 25, 2017}}</ref>
In the [[Royal Rumble (2017)|2017 Royal Rumble]] match on January 29, Reigns entered as the surprise last entrant despite losing a WWE Universal Championship match against [[Kevin Owens]] earlier that 11, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In February 2017, Meltzer said it was "obvious" that WWE's push of Reigns "will never end".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meltzer|first1=Dave|authorlink1=Dave Meltzer|title=It will never end. Isn't that obvious by now.|url=https://twitter.com/davemeltzerWON/status/827309511874523136|accessdate=February 3, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213041025/https://twitter.com/davemeltzerWON/status/827309511874523136|archive-date=February 13, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Later that month, wrestling podcaster [[Peter Rosenberg]] lamented that—unlike the similarly powerful Hulk Hogan—Reigns "doesn't show vulnerability, ever".<ref>{{cite episode|title=The Fast Lane To Fastlane|series=Cheap Heat|network=[[ESPN Radio]]|date=February 23, 2017|minutes=62}}</ref>
=== Establishment as face of the company (2017–2018) === On March 5 at [[Fastlane (2017)|Fastlane]], Reigns defeated Strowman and became the first man to successfully pin him in WWE.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Benigno|first1=Anthony|title=Roman Reigns def. Braun Strowman|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wwefastlane/2017/roman-reigns-vs-braun-strowman-results|work=WWE|accessdate=March 5, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170306154307/http://www.wwe.com/shows/wwefastlane/2017/roman-reigns-vs-braun-strowman-results|archive-date=March 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Although the match itself was praised, this booking choice was poorly received by critics, who agreed that, despite adding nothing to Reigns' reputation, the match's ending would severely hurt Strowman's "unstoppable beast" image, "undid" all the momentum Strowman had acquired during the previous months and might even damage his career and future in WWE.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Powell|first1=Jason|title=3/5 Powell's WWE Fastlane Live [[File:Reigns vs Lesnar WM34 crop.jpg|thumb|[[Brock Lesnar]] and Reigns face off at [[WrestleMania 34]]]] In March 2017, Dave Meltzer reported that WWE's long term plans ("which obviously could change") for 2018's WrestleMania 34 was to "once again build for a year and have the big coronation" for Reigns, who would still be a heroic character "between now and then" and beat Brock Lesnar for the WWE Universal Championship "to fully replace John Cena as the lead babyface of the company",<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meltzer|first1=Dave|title=March 20, 2017 Wrestling Observer Newsletter: Situation with Broken Matt Hardy and Anthem Sports, Wrestlemania card, more|url=http://members.f4wonline.com/wrestling-observer-newsletter/march-20-2017-wrestling-observer-newsletter-situation-broken-matt|website=f4wonline.com|accessdate=March 20, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170320132137/http://members.f4wonline.com/wrestling-observer-newsletter/march-20-2017-wrestling-observer-newsletter-situation-broken-matt|archive-date=March 20, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> while the "idea" for Lesnar's role "for years now" was "to become a monster, be unbeatable, run through everybody, and then lose to Roman Reigns".<ref>{{cite web|title=WOR: Paige, Toyota, PWG, CMLL, UFC, tons more!|url=http://media001.f4wonline.com/dmdocuments/031817wo.mp3|website=f4wonline.com|accessdate=March 19, 2017}}</ref> At WrestleMania 33 on April 2, Reigns was booed before, during and after the main event (his third WrestleMania main event in a row), which saw Reigns beating The Undertaker, who seemingly retired.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burdick|first=Michael|title=Roman Reigns def. The Undertaker|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/33/undertaker-vs-roman-reigns-results|work=WWE|accessdate=April 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404043151/http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/33/undertaker-vs-roman-reigns-results|archive-date=April 4, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://prowrestling.net/site/2017/04/02/powells-wrestlemania-33-live-review-undertaker-vs-roman-reigns-goldberg-vs-brock-lesnar-wwe-universal-championship-aj-styles-vs-shane-mcmahon-seth-rollins-vs-triple-h/|title=Powell's WrestleMania 33 live review: Undertaker vs. Roman Reigns, Goldberg vs. Brock Lesnar for the WWE Universal Championship, AJ Styles vs. Shane McMahon, Seth Rollins vs. Triple H in an unsanctioned match|last1=Powell|first1=Jason|work=Pro Wreslting Dot Net|accessdate=April 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170403113529/http://prowrestling.net/site/2017/04/02/powells-wrestlemania-33-live-review-undertaker-vs-roman-reigns-goldberg-vs-brock-lesnar-wwe-universal-championship-aj-styles-vs-shane-mcmahon-seth-rollins-vs-triple-h/|archive-date=April 3, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Before the match, ''Pro Wrestling Insider'''s [[Dave Scherer]] predicted that if Reigns beat and retired The Undertaker, then "the fans that hate him will hate him forever".<ref name=hate4ever>{{cite web|last1=Scherer|first1=Dave|title=Full WrestleMania 33 blog|url=http://pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=108830&p=5|website=pwinsider.com|accessdate=April 3, match, WWE "did clearly turn down the sound" from the audience "and then they hit the pyro", but boos were still heard during a break in Reigns' music being played.<ref name=hate4ever/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Keller|first1=Wade|title=WrestleMania 33 main card report 4/2|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/site/2017/04/02/kellers-wrestlemania-33-main-card-report-42-reigns-vs-undertaker-lesnar-vs-goldberg-owens-vs-jericho-orton-vs-wyatt-styles-vs-shane/|website=pwtorch.com|accessdate=April 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On the ''Raw'' after WrestleMania, Reigns was loudly booed and the crowd microphone volumes were turned down when he appeared, but multiple chants of "[[Matt Hardy|Delete]]", "Fuck you, Roman", "You suck", "Asshole", "Roman sucks", "Shut the fuck up" and "Go away" were still heard before Reigns chose to speak.<ref name=PostWM33>{{cite web|last1=Keller|first1=Wade|title=Keller's WWE Monday Night Raw 4/3|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/site/2017/04/03/kellers-wwe-monday-night-raw-23-remarkable-opening-ten-minutes-raw-history-perhaps-crowd-berates-reigns/|website=pwtorch.com|accessdate=April 4, 4, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> After that segment, WWE commentators labelled the post-WrestleMania 33 crowd as "non-traditional WWE fans" who may cheer for those they normally boo and boo those they normally cheer "all in the name of fun", which echoed similar comments a year prior for the post-WrestleMania 32 crowd.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ferguson|first1=LaToya|title=The vicious cycle of WWE continues with the RAW after WrestleMania|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/vicious-cycle-wwe-continues-raw-after-wrestlemania-234815|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=April 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407032328/http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/vicious-cycle-wwe-continues-raw-after-wrestlemania-234815|archive-date=April 7, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''Pro Wrestling Torch'' editor Wade Keller wrote that these comments would anger fans as "genuine dissatisfaction with the product is reframed by Vince McMahon's propaganda machine" – Undertaker received the usual reaction from fans, as did Reigns, just more intensely.<ref name=PostWM33/> Following Reigns' victory over The Undertaker and given that Reigns was reportedly selling more merchandise than any other full-time WWE wrestler (John Cena, who sold more, was considered a part-timer), ''[[Forbes]]'' writer Blake Oestriecher declared Reigns as "indeed the new face of WWE, one who could remain in that spot for the next decade".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/blakeoestriecher/2017/04/01/this-week-in-wwe-biz-roman-reigns-sales-brock-lesnar-vs-goldberg-plans-seth-rollins-feud-more/#4eeefa3f6143|title=This Week In WWE Biz: Roman Reigns Sales, Brock Lesnar Vs. In a December 2017 interview, Anoaʻi called himself "the best performer, in-ring, in the world right now". In response, Brian Campbell of [[CBS Sports]] wrote that Anoaʻi "isn't even the best performer in his own company" and "wouldn't even finish in the top five" in the world. Meanwhile, fellow wrestler [[Kenny Omega]] commented that "it sounds so ridiculous" and that there was "no possible way" Anoaʻi believed what he said.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Brian|title=Kenny Omega takes issue with Roman Reigns' claim: Who is the best in the world?|url=https://www.cbssports.com/wwe/news/kenny-omega-takes-issue-with-roman-reigns-claim-who-is-the-best-in-the-world/|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|accessdate=April 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180412211813/https://www.cbssports.com/wwe/news/kenny-omega-takes-issue-with-roman-reigns-claim-who-is-the-best-in-the-world/|archive-date=April 12, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Also that month, WWE vice president Triple H said regarding Reigns: "I think he is one of the best that WWE have right now [...] the truth is, and some people will listen to this and want to argue against it, but honestly most of the people who argue against it aren't qualified to make that argument. I am".<ref>{{cite web|title=Triple H on WWE's tour of Abu Dhabi and facing Roman Reigns|url=https://www.thenational.ae/sport/other-sport/triple-h-on-wwe-s-tour-of-abu-dhabi-and-facing-roman-reigns-1.681581|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|accessdate=December 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171207142544/https://www.thenational.ae/sport/other-sport/triple-h-on-wwe-s-tour-of-abu-dhabi-and-facing-roman-reigns-1.681581|archive-date=December 7, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In March 2018, Reigns said regarding his reception that "everyone wants to see you do good, but not too good"; and that there is "possible jealousy" from fans regarding his "major success".<ref name=jealousy>{{cite web|last1=Droste|first1=Ryan|title=Roman Reigns Has a Theory on Why Fans Boo Him|url=http://popculture.com/wwe/2018/03/25/roman-reigns-wwe-fans-boo/|publisher=Pop Culture Media|date=March 25, 2018|accessdate=March 30, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330143540/http://popculture.com/wwe/2018/03/25/roman-reigns-wwe-fans-boo/|archive-date=March 30, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Before WrestleMania 34 in April 2018, Reigns said that he would not try to change for anyone that did not like him.<ref name=change>{{cite web|last1=Staszewski|first1=Joseph|title=Roman Reigns' Brock Lesnar beef not all about WrestleMania|url=https://nypost.com/2018/04/04/roman-reigns-brock-lesnar-beef-not-all-about-wrestlemania/amp/|work=[[New York Post]]|date=April 4, 2018|accessdate=April 7, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180407184254/https://nypost.com/2018/04/04/roman-reigns-brock-lesnar-beef-not-all-about-wrestlemania/amp/|archive-date=April 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Reigns' main event match with Lesnar at WrestleMania 34 was resoundingly rejected by the crowd, as Reigns was booed while the crowd played with beach balls and instead chanted "CM Punk", "Boring" and "This is awful!"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Needelman|first1=Joshua|title=WWE WrestleMania 34: Ronda Rousey wins debut; Daniel Bryan returns; Brock Lesnar beats Roman Reigns in dud main event|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/sports/wp/2018/04/08/wwe-wrestlemania-34-live|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=9 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409054223/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/sports/wp/2018/04/08/wwe-wrestlemania-34-live/|archivedate=9 April 2018|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Keller|first1=Wade|title=Keller's WWE WrestleMania 34 report: Lesnar vs. Reigns, Styles vs. Nakamura, Charlotte vs. Asuka, Rousey’s debut, Bryan’s return, Battle Royals, more|url=https://www.pwtorch.com/site/2018/04/08/kellers-wwe-wrestlemania-34-report-lesnar-vs-reigns-styles-vs-nakamura-charlotte-vs-asuka-rouseys-debut-bryans-return-battle-royals-more/|website=pwtorch.com|accessdate=9 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409110158/https://www.pwtorch.com/site/2018/04/08/kellers-wwe-wrestlemania-34-report-lesnar-vs-reigns-styles-vs-nakamura-charlotte-vs-asuka-rouseys-debut-bryans-return-battle-royals-more/|archivedate=9 April 2018|df=}}</ref><ref name=meltzer34>{{cite web|last1=Meltzer|first1=Dave|title=WWE WrestleMania 34 live results, news & recap|url=https://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-results/wwe-wrestlemania-34-live-results-news-recap-254991|website=f4wonline.com|accessdate=9 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409041313/https://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-results/wwe-wrestlemania-34-live-results-news-recap-254991|archivedate=9 April 2018|df=}}</ref> Troy L. Smith of [[Cleveland.com]] concluded that this match was the worst ever WrestleMania main event due to the "utter disdain" it produced, with there never being a more "disinterested" crowd for a WrestleMania main event.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Troy L|title=WrestleMania 34: Was Lesnar-Reigns the worst main event ever?|url=http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2018/04/wrestlemania_34_was_lesnar-rei.html|publisher=[[Cleveland.com]]|accessdate=9 April 2018|date=9 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180410073312/http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2018/04/wrestlemania_34_was_lesnar-rei.html|archivedate=10 April 2018|df=}}</ref> Meltzer wrote that Reigns' loss was "done for sympathy for Reigns when it was over to make him a babyface as they concentrated on showing him all beaten up".<ref name=meltzer34/>
{{quote box|quote=I've done what I'm supposed to do and that's draw people into the building. [...] I think the way I can fight is to just continue to do what I do – to continue to show up. What I and everybody in WWE thinks is to go out there and work hard and continue to show why I am the guy. It's not easy doing this every single day, going to every single town, and getting a reaction.|source=<small>Anoa'i in a 2018 interview on the recent negative crowd reception.<ref name=sunsport18>{{cite web|last1=Fordy|first1=Tom|title=WWE ace Roman Reigns opens up on fans booing, beating Undertaker and being the full-time main man|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/6290449/wwe-roman-reigns-undertaker-lesnar/|publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|accessdate=16 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180515233900/https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/6290449/wwe-roman-reigns-undertaker-lesnar/|archive-date=15 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref></small>|align=right|width=30%}} On April 30, the go-home edition of ''Raw'' before [[Backlash (2018)|Backlash]], Reigns was met with great hostility from the crowd in Montreal. Reigns was heavily booed, in contrast to his rival [[Samoa Joe]], who received overwhelming cheers despite being portrayed as a heel.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://stillrealtous.com/samoa-joe-on-why-fans-cheer-him-and-boo-roman-reigns/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-05-16 a large number of the crowd in New Jersey reportedly walked out of the arena during Reigns' match with Joe, a match Reigns was booked to win.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/othersport/957593/WWE-news-Vince-McMahon-Roman-Reigns-Samoa-Joe-Backlash-Braun-Strowman|title=WWE news: How Vince McMahon reacted to fans walking out of Roman Reigns v Samoa Joe howler|work=Daily Express|date=May 10, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.thesportster.com/news/fans-leave-backlash-main-event-roman-reigns-samoa-joe/ |title=Fans Leave |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180513151955/https://www.thesportster.com/news/fans-leave-backlash-main-event-roman-reigns-samoa-joe/ |archive-date=2018-05-13 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://uproxx.com/prowrestling/wwe-backlash-main-event-walk-out/ |title=WWE Fans Were Not Happy With The Backlash Main Event |access-date=2018-05-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180513081923/https://uproxx.com/prowrestling/wwe-backlash-main-event-walk-out/ |archive-date=2018-05-13 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> Brian Campbell and Adam Silverstein of [[CBS Sports]] wrote that it was "just impossible to ignore how poorly WWE continues to treat its own fanbase...this has escalated to the point where the psychology and storyline simply makes no sense in ways that can't be good for business".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Brian|last2=Silverstein|first2=Adam|title=2018 WWE Backlash results, recap, grades: Styles-Nakamura, Reigns finishes frustrate fans|url=https://www.cbssports.com/wwe/news/2018-wwe-backlash-results-recap-grades-styles-nakamura-reigns-finishes-frustrate-fans|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|accessdate=7 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507151615/https://www.cbssports.com/wwe/news/2018-wwe-backlash-results-recap-grades-styles-nakamura-reigns-finishes-frustrate-fans/|archive-date=7 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Meltzer described that "lots of people were leaving" during Reigns' match and that the crowd was chanting that the match was boring.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meltzer|first1=Dave|authorlink1=Dave Meltzer|title=WWE Backlash live results: AJ Styles vs. Shinsuke Nakamura|url=https://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-results/wwe-backlash-live-results-aj-styles-vs-shinsuke-nakamura-257151|publisher=Wrestling Observer|accessdate=8 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507153718/https://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-results/wwe-backlash-live-results-aj-styles-vs-shinsuke-nakamura-257151|archive-date=7 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ''Pro Wrestling Dot Net'' editor Jason Powell described WWE Chairman Vince McMahon as "completely insane when it comes to his obsession with Reigns being his company’s top babyface" when the "definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results". Powell went on to mock WWE's "frequently repeated line about how WWE listens to its fans" and another WWE claim that "any reaction is a good reaction".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Powell|first1=Jason|title=WWE Backlash Hit List|url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/05/07/wwe-backlash-hit-list-roman-reigns-vs-samoa-joe-seth-rollins-vs-the-miz-for-the-intercontinental-championship-aj-styles-vs-shinsuke-nakamura-in-a-no-dq-match-for-the-wwe-championship/|website=prowrestling.net|accessdate=8 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507220941/https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/05/07/wwe-backlash-hit-list-roman-reigns-vs-samoa-joe-seth-rollins-vs-the-miz-for-the-intercontinental-championship-aj-styles-vs-shinsuke-nakamura-in-a-no-dq-match-for-the-wwe-championship/|archive-date=7 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Meltzer said that the character of Reigns was being modeled after [[Daniel Bryan]]'s, with the similar storyline that WWE "management is screwing him over and that's why he's not the champion", and that despite fans not buying this storyline, no one in WWE had a better idea for Reigns.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rumor: WWE Boosting Roman Reigns With Fabled Daniel Bryan Storyline|url=http://popculture.com/wwe/2018/05/08/roman-reigns-wwe-plan-rip-off-daniel-bryan-rumor/|publisher=Pop Culture Media|accessdate=23 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180524003526/http://popculture.com/wwe/2018/05/08/roman-reigns-wwe-plan-rip-off-daniel-bryan-rumor/|archive-date=24 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Even though Reigns lost his matches to Lesnar at WrestleMania 34 and at the [[WWE Greatest Royal Rumble|Greatest Royal Rumble]], it was still indicated by the company that the two would face each other again at [[SummerSlam (2018)|SummerSlam]].
At [[Money in the Bank (2018)|Money in the Bank]], Reigns' match with [[Jinder Mahal]] was widely rejected by crowd in Illinois. Within the first two minutes of the match, once again, chants of "CM Punk" and "Boring" were heard. The crowd continued to ignore the match by playing with beach balls, performing the Mexican wave, and continued chants of other wrestlers names, booing officials who confiscated the beach balls, and continued negative chants about the match. Every other match on the card, however, was well received. In July 2018 on ''Raw'', Reigns told fans who "boo", "hate", or claim that he "is being crammed down our throats" to "learn to like it or close your mouth." Meanwhile, Wade Keller of ''Pro Wrestling Torch'' criticised Anoa’i for arguing that he deserves his push due to hard work and winning many titles. Keller pointed out that Anoa’i "doesn't work harder than dozens of other colleagues, yet he acts as if he's special", and that Reigns' title wins were "granted by Vince McMahon."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Keller |first1=Wade |title=7/23 WWE Raw Results |url=https://www.pwtorch.com/site/2018/07/23/7-23-wwe-raw-results-kellers-report-on-the-historic-announcements-by-vince-stephanie-and-triple-h-plus-more-summerslam-developments/ |website=pwtorch.com |accessdate=July 24, 2018}}</ref> At [[Extreme Rules (2018)|Extreme Rules]], Reigns again received overwhelming boos while his opponent [[Bobby Lashley]] was wildly cheered. During the match, security threatened to eject anti-Reigns fans and confiscated anti-Reigns signs.{{cn|date=August 2018}} Lashley received wild cheers for his victory over Roman, as well as chants of "Thank you Lashley!"<ref>https://comicbook.com/wwe/2018/07/25/roman-reigns-wwe-bobby-on-crowd-reaction/</ref>
=== Universal Champion and hiatus (2018–present)=== In August 2018 at SummerSlam, the audience started out giving Reigns a fairly mixed reaction during his entrance. Following Braun Strowman's announcement of his plan to cash-in post match, the crowd cheered. A brief chant of "Let's go Roman/Roman Sucks" filled the arena at one point, followed by chants of "You both suck" directed at both Lesnar and Reigns. in the ring. When Reigns pinned Lesnar to win the WWE Universal Championship, the crowd cheered. <ref>https://www.mykhel.com/wwe/wwe-rumour-brock-lesnar-not-defending-universal-title-until-summerslam-091335.html</ref><ref name="SSlam2018">{{cite web|last=Powell|first=Jason|title=Powell’s WWE SummerSlam 2018 live review: Brock Lesnar vs. Roman Reigns for the WWE Universal Championship, AJ Styles vs. Samoa Joe for the WWE Championship, Alexa Bliss vs. Ronda Rousey for the Raw Women’s Championship, Daniel Bryan vs. The Miz|url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/08/19/powells-wwe-summerslam-2018-live-review-brock-lesnar-vs-roman-reigns-for-the-wwe-universal-championship-aj-styles-vs-samoa-joe-for-the-wwe-championship-alexa-bliss-vs-ronda-rousey-for-the-raw/|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|accessdate=August 19, 2018}}</ref>
The following night on ''Raw'', Reigns was again booed early in the show, but received a mixed reaction for suggesting that he defend his newly-won championship against [[Finn Bálor]] later that night. After beating Bálor, Reigns was again heavily booed by the crowd, which increased in intensity after the match when Braun Strowman attempted to cash in his Money in the Bank title shot. The subsequent Shield reunion and attack on Strowman was positively received by the Brooklyn audience, but was viewed by many as a cheap attempt to garner positive reactions for Reigns.<ref name="Raw08202018">{{cite web|url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/08/20/8-20-powells-wwe-raw-live-tv-review-the-night-after-wwe-summerslam/|title=8/20 Powell’s WWE Raw Live TV Review: The night after WWE SummerSlam, new champions Roman Reigns and Ronda Rousey, Triple H appearance, Dean Ambrose vs. Dolph Ziggler|date=August 20, 2018|last=Powell|first=Jason|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|accessdate=August 22, 2018}}</ref> At [[Hell in a Cell (2018)|Hell in a Cell]], Reigns defended his Universal Championship against Braun Strowman, during which Reigns was booed heavily while the villainous Strowman was wildly cheered by fans. The match was victim to high controversy, with the first incident being when special guest referee [[Mick Foley]] counted Reigns down for a three count, but instead of Strowman getting the victory, the pinfall was simply ignored, with the second being when the match ended in a no contest after interference from a returning Brock Lesnar. After the match ended, the network stream abruptly ended with many saying this was done to avoid broadcasting the heavy boos from fans with many taking to social media claiming that chants of "Bullshit!" and "We want refunds!" along with heavy booing broke out as Reigns, Strowman and Lesnar all had walked to the back.<ref name="HIAC2018">{{cite web|last=Powell|first=Jason|title=Powell’s WWE Hell in a Cell 2018 live review: Roman Reigns vs. Braun Strowman in an HIAC for the WWE Universal Championship with Mick Foley as referee, AJ Styles vs. Samoa Joe for the WWE Title, Jeff Hardy vs. Randy Orton in an HIAC match|url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/09/16/powells-wwe-hell-in-a-cell-2018-live-review-roman-reigns-vs-braun-strowman-in-an-hiac-for-the-wwe-universal-championship-with-mick-foley-as-referee-aj-styles-vs-samoa-joe-for-the-wwe-title-jeff/|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|accessdate=September 16, 2018}}</ref>
On the October 22, 2018 episode of ''Raw'', Reigns announced that he was re-diagnosed with leukemia after 11 years and would be taking a hiatus to treat it. As a result, he relinquished the Universal Championship, ending his reign of 64 days. Reigns initially received a mixed reaction upon entering the arena, but was welcomed with a positive reception after his announcement of leukemia was made.<ref name="Raw10222018">{{cite web|last1=Powell|first1=Jason|title=10/22 Powell’s WWE Raw Live TV Review: Roman Reigns announces he has leukemia, forfeits the WWE Universal Championship, Drew McIntyre and Dolph Ziggler vs. Seth Rollins and Dean Ambrose for the Raw Tag Titles, Ronda Rousey and Nikki Bella contract signing for WWE Evolution, Triple H and Shawn Michaels appear|url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/10/22/10-22-powells-wwe-raw-live-tv-review-drew-mcintyre-and-dolph-ziggler-vs-seth-rollins-and-dean-ambrose-for-the-raw-tag-titles-ronda-rousey-and-nikki-bella-contract-signing-for-wwe-evolution/|work=Pro Wreslting Dot Net|accessdate=October 22, 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
