revision.text:
'''Pub Philosophy''' is a term sometimes used to describe organised gatherings in [[public house]]s for [[philosophical]] discussion.<ref>Billington, R: ''Living Philosophy An Introduction to Moral Thought, 3rd Edition''. Routledge, 2003.</ref> Several series of events in the [[United Kingdom]] and elsewhere offer pub philosophy in a variety of formats, typically involving an invited speaker and some degree of open discussion. Among the more long-standing of these are:
*Big Ideas (based in London, UK) https://web.archive.org/web/20100912055756/http://bigi.org.uk/ *Kant's Cave (held in London, UK, by [[Philosophy For All]]) *Living Philosophy (based in [[Tintern]], [[Wales]] UK) *PhiloMadrid (based in Madrid, Spain) *Philosophy In Pubs (based in Liverpool, UK) http://www.philosophyinpubs.co.uk *PIPS Brighton (based in Brighton, UK) http://www.pips-brighton.org.uk/ *The [[Stoa]] (based in [[Faversham]], Kent, UK) *[[Skeptics in the Pub]] *Thinking While Drinking (based in [[San Diego]], [[California]]) http://thinkingwhiledrinking.org
Pub Philosophy groups, while often run by amateurs, have sometimes been recruited by more mainstream institutions to provide a distinctively participatory public forum. Such alliances have included [[Tate Liverpool]] and [[University of Chester]] working with Philosophy in Pubs,<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/eventseducation/talksdiscussions/22109.htm Tate Liverpool] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101108093210/http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/eventseducation/talksdiscussions/22109.htm |date=2010-11-08 }} Retrieved 02-09-10.</ref> the [[Brighton Science Festival]] 2010 working with PIPS Brighton<ref>[http://www.brightonscience.com/2010/programme/pips.html Brighton Science Festival 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120721203722/http://www.brightonscience.com/2010/programme/pips.html |date=2012-07-21 }} Retrieved 02-09-10</ref> and the [[London School of Economics]] producing an event in collaboration with Big Ideas.<ref>[http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/forumForEuropeanPhilosophy/events/PanelDiscussion.htm London School of Economics] Retrieved 02-09-10</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Beer|Wine|Drink|Culture|Companies|Business and economics}} *[[List of public house topics]] *[[Café Philosophique]] *[[Society for Advancing Philosophical Enquiry and Reflection in Education|SAPERE]] *[[Socrates Cafe]] *[[Viennese café]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://bigi.org.uk/2007/02/28/a-pub-philosophy-manifesto/ Big Ideas] *[http://pfalondon.org/kant.html Kant's Cave] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100724232831/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/p.tofts/pips-brighton/index.html PIPS Brighton] *[http://www.philosophyinpubs.co.uk Philosophy In Pubs National] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111007032106/http://www.livingphilosophy.co.uk/index.php?page=living-philosophy Living Philosophy] *[http://philomadrid.blogspot.com/ PhiloMadrid] *[http://www.stoa.org.uk/ Faversham Stoa] *[http://skeptic.org.uk/events/skeptics-in-the-pub Skeptics in the Pub] *[https://archive.is/20121224025331/http://www.kingstonphilosophycafe.org.uk/ Kingston Philosophy Cafe] *[http://thinkingwhiledrinking.org/ Thinking While Drinking]
[[Category:Philosophy education]] [[Category:Philosophy events]] [[Category:Philosophy organizations]] [[Category:Pubs]] [[Category:Public philosophy]]
{{philosophy-stub}}

{{Underlinked|date=March 2014}} {{other|Puss in the corner (disambiguation){{!}}Puss in the corner}}
{{Infobox Game| subject_name=Puss in the Corner | image_link= | image_caption= | players=5 | ages=3 and up | setup_time= 1 minute or less | playing_time= No limit | complexity=Low | strategy=High | random_chance=Low | skills=[[Running]] | }}
'''Puss in the corner''' is a [[children's game]] for five players.
==Description== A yard, court, room, or other square area with four corners, posts, or trees [[equidistant]] from one another is chosen as the playing arena. One player is nominated "Puss" and takes his place in the center of the arena. Each of the other four players selects one of the corners and takes their place there. Play begins with the four corner players attempting to exchange places with each other in any direction. "Puss" attempts to gain a corner during the exchange. Should they succeed, the player left without a corner becomes "Puss" and takes their place in the center of the arena. Play resumes in a similar manner. Should players A and B attempt to exchange corners and A gains B's corner but A's corner is gained by "Puss", then B becomes "Puss" rather than A.
==References== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=XiMOAAAAQAAJ&vq=puss%20in%20the%20corner&pg=PA23#v=snippet&q=puss%20in%20the%20corner&f=false ''Boys' Own Book; a Complete Encyclopedia of Athletic, Scientific, Outdoor and Indoor Sports. With Illustrations.''] New York: James Millier, Publisher. 1881.
==Further reading== *Child, Lydia Maria (1863) ''The Girl's Own Book''; new ed. by Mrs. R. Vallentine. London: Tegg; p. 13-14 (Puss, Puss in the Corner!)
[[Category:Children's games]]

{{About|the 1998 video game|other South Park video games|List of South Park video games}} {{Infobox video game | title = South Park | image = Southpark video game cover-1-.jpg | caption = PlayStation boxart for North America | developer = [[Iguana Entertainment]]

[[Game Boy Color]] (cancelled/leaked in 2018) | released = '''Nintendo 64'''{{cite web |url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/n64/198710-south-park/data |title=South Park for Nintendo 64 |publisher=[[GameFAQs]] |accessdate=2013-07-08}}
{{vgrelease|NA|December 12, 1998|EU|May 3, 1999}}'''Microsoft Windows'''{{cite web |url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/132697-south-park/data |title=South Park for PC |publisher=[[GameFAQs]] |accessdate=2013-07-08}}
{{vgrelease|NA|March 9, 1999}}'''PlayStation'''{{cite web |url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/ps/198711-south-park/data |title=South Park for PlayStation |publisher=[[GameFAQs]] |accessdate=2013-07-08}}
{{vgrelease|NA|September 30, 1999|EU|2000}}
'''Game Boy Color'''{{vgrelease|NA|Cancelled}} | genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]], [[First-person shooter|first-person shooter]] (PlayStation/PC/Nintendo 64)
[[Platform game|Platformer]]
(Game Boy Color) | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | producer= David Dienstbier | designer= Jeff Everett
Neill Glancy | composer= Darren Mitchell
[[Tim Follin]]
(Game Boy Color) }} '''''South Park''''' is a [[first-person shooter]] [[Adventure game|adventure]] [[video game]] based on the American animated comedy series [[South Park|of the same name]]. The game was developed by [[Iguana Entertainment]] and published by [[Acclaim Entertainment]] for the [[Nintendo 64]] in 1998 for North America and in 1999 for Europe. It was later ported to [[Microsoft Windows]] in 1999 and released in North America only. The [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] port was developed by [[Appaloosa Interactive]] in 1999. A [[Game Boy Color]] version was in development, but it was eventually canceled by creators [[Matt Stone]] and [[Trey Parker]], feelings the game would not fit in a console marketed towards children. However, they did keep a few copies of the Game Boy Color version to commemorate what was originally started as the first ''South Park'' game.{{cite web|url= http://www.unseen64.net/2008/04/05/south-park-gbc-cancelled/| title= South Park [Unreleased] |accessdate= 2008-07-08|publisher=Unseen 64.net}} Despite the Nintendo 64 version's positive reception, the PC and PlayStation versions of ''South Park'' were [[List of video games notable for negative reception|panned by critics]]. A [[Sega Dreamcast]] version was planned for a 2000 release, but was cancelled during development for unknown reasons. In 2018, a [[ROM image]] of the Game Boy Color version was leaked online.{{cite web|url=https://www.lostmediawiki.com/South_Park_%28found_GBC_game;_1998%29|title=South Park (found GBC game; 1998)|website=lostmediawiki.com|accessdate=2018-08-08}} ==Gameplay== ''South Park'' is a [[first-person shooter]]. The game's single player mode places the player in control of one of the four main characters of South Park ([[Eric Cartman|Cartman]], [[Kyle Broflovski|Kyle]], [[Stan Marsh|Stan]] or [[Kenny McCormick|Kenny]]). The player must defeat a variety of enemies using the various weapons found throughout each stage in order to reach the exit point at the end. In addition to completing levels, the player must also prevent large enemies in the stage (dubbed 'Tanks') from reaching the exit before they do. If they fail to do so, they will be forced to defend South Park from the 'Tanks' in a short minigame after the stage. ===Multiplayer=== In Head-to-Head mode, the players select a level, characters, and game style (time limited, damage limited, or unending). The [[Microsoft Windows]] version allows for online head-to-head play. In the PlayStation and Nintendo 64 versions, upon reaching select stages in single player mode, codes are revealed. These can then be input into the "Cheesy Poofs Decoder" to unlock additional characters for Head-to-Head play. All characters are unlocked in the Microsoft Windows version. ==Story== A mysterious comet is approaching the earth, described by the opening narration as a force of concentrated evil that no force of good can stand against. As it comes closer, South Park is beset by enemies, including rabid mutant turkeys, deformed clones of the townsfolk, alien visitors, berserk robots, and sentient killer toys. Stan, Kyle, Cartman and Kenny hear about the dangers from Chef, and take up arms to investigate their sources and defend the town. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GR = (N64) 67.11%{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/n64/198710-south-park/index.html|title=South Park (N64)|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=2012-09-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040115141014/http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages4/198710.asp|archivedate=2004-01-15|deadurl=no}}
(PC) 51.72%{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/132697-south-park/index.html|title=South Park (PC)|publisher=GameRankings|accessdate=2012-09-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041125055343/http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages4/132697.asp|archivedate=2004-11-25 |deadurl=no}}
(PS) 41.22%{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps/198711-south-park/index.html|title=South Park for PlayStation|publisher=GameRankings}} | Allgame = (PC) {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=17717|title=South Park (PC) - Overview|last=Penniment|first=Brad|publisher=[[AllGame]]|accessdate=2012-09-27}}
(N64) {{Rating|2.5|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=14609&tab=review|title=South Park (N64) - Review|last=Marriott|first=Scott Alan|publisher=Allgame|accessdate=2012-09-27}}
(PS) {{Rating|2|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=19249&tab=review|title=South Park (PS) - Review|last=Baker|first=Christopher Michael|publisher=Allgame|accessdate=2012-09-27}} | Edge = (N64) 4/10{{cite journal|title=South Park (N64)|author=Edge staff|magazine=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]|issue=68|date=February 1999}} | GI = (N64) 7/10{{cite journal|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/reviews/review_detail.cfm?ITEM_ID=1279|title=South Park - Nintendo 64|magazine=[[Game Informer]]|date=January 1999|pages=34–35|accessdate=2012-09-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001026032225/http://www.gameinformer.com/reviews/review_detail.cfm?ITEM_ID=1279|archivedate=2000-10-26|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://gameinformer.com/reviews/reviews_system.cfm?SYSTEM=Nintendo+64|title=Game Informer Magazine - Reviews (N64)|publisher=[[Game Informer]]|accessdate=2012-09-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001016183614/http://gameinformer.com/reviews/reviews_system.cfm?SYSTEM=Nintendo+64|archivedate=2000-10-16|deadurl=yes}} | GamePro = (PS) {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web|url=http://gamepro.com/sony/psx/games/reviews/3824.shtml|title=South Park Review for PlayStation|author=The Burn Out|publisher=''[[GamePro]]''|accessdate=2012-09-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050212134359/http://gamepro.com/sony/psx/games/reviews/3824.shtml|archivedate=2005-02-12|deadurl=yes}}
(N64) {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web|url=http://gamepro.com/nintendo/n64/games/reviews/110.shtml|title=South Park Review for N64|last=Elektro|first=Dan|publisher=''GamePro''|accessdate=2012-09-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051120013336/http://gamepro.com/nintendo/n64/games/reviews/110.shtml|archivedate=2005-11-20|deadurl=yes}}
(PC) {{Rating|2.5|5}}{{cite web|url=http://gamepro.com/computer/pc/games/reviews/717.shtml|title=South Park Review for PC|last=Knibbe|first=Willem|publisher=''GamePro''|accessdate=2012-09-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050209062349/http://gamepro.com/computer/pc/games/reviews/717.shtml|archivedate=2005-02-09|deadurl=yes}} | GameRev = (N64) C−{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/south-park|title=South Park Review|author=Colin|publisher=[[Game Revolution]]|date=1999-01-01|accessdate=2012-09-27}} | GSpot = (N64) 5.8/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/south-park-review/1900-2545235/|title=South Park Review for Nintendo 64|last=Gerstmann|first=Jeff|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=1998-12-28|accessdate=2013-10-20}}
(PC) 4.1/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/south-park-review/1900-2533122/|title=South Park Review for PC|last=Kasavin|first=Greg|publisher=GameSpot|date=1999-03-11|accessdate=2013-10-20}}
(PS) 1.4/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/south-park-review/1900-2549391/|title=South Park Review for PlayStation|last=Gerstmann|first=Jeff|publisher=GameSpot|date=1999-10-15|accessdate=2013-10-20}} | IGN = (N64) 6.2/10{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1999/01/12/south-park-6|title=South Park (N64)|last=Schneider|first=Peer|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=1999-01-11}}
(PC) 4.5/10{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1999/03/13/south-park-5|title=South Park (PC)|last=Blevins|first=Tal|publisher=IGN|date=1999-03-12}}
(PS) 2/10{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1999/10/20/south-park|title=South Park (PS)|last=Austin|first=Dean|publisher=IGN|date=1999-10-19}} | NP = 7.5/10{{cite journal|title=South Park|magazine=[[Nintendo Power]]|volume=116|date=January 1999}} | PCGUS = 40%{{cite journal|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/reviews/1325.html|title=South Park|magazine=[[PC Gamer]]|date=June 1999|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000306143044/http://www.pcgamer.com/reviews/1325.html|archivedate=2000-03-06|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2014-11-28}} }} ''South Park''{{'}}s reception depended on the platform. Overall, the game was met with overwhelmingly negative critical reception with the PC and PlayStation versions, while the Nintendo 64 version generally received positive reviews from critics. The PlayStation and PC versions received poor reception due to the bad graphics, poor visuals and bad voice acting. The Nintendo 64 version received the best reviews upon release. Aggregating review website [[GameRankings]] gave the [[Nintendo 64]] version 67.11%, the PC version 51.72% and the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] version 41.22%. [[GameSpot]] gave the PlayStation version a 1.4/10, stating that "''South Park'' is definitely one of those games that is bound to come up when you start thinking about the worst game you've ever played." [[IGN]] called the PlayStation version "frustrating" due to poor graphics, repetition of the voice acting, and lack of play value for the head-to-head mode. GameSpot stated in the PC version that "A good license and good graphics aren't enough." The voice acting, done by the original voice actors, was criticized for being repetitive, isolated, and old. The weapons of the game were also criticized for being unprofessional. Despite the negative reception from the Windows and PlayStation versions, the Nintendo 64 version was praised for its 3D graphics and storyline, with IGN calling the game "just as funny as the Comedy Central series." GameSpot stated in the Nintendo 64 version that the level design was "really not very good on its own, but given the license, it at least makes sense." {{clear}} ==Sequel== A spiritual sequel in the style of a sandbox action-adventure game was in development for the [[PlayStation 2]], [[Gamecube]] and [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], but was not finished. Little was known about the game until a build was found on an Xbox development kit, but only video footage of the beta build has been released to the public. The footage appears to showcase the PlayStation 2 version, due to the visual button displays used in the game. A cutscene from the game was even leaked on YouTube showing Cartman in a mental hospital.{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/09/30/the-story-behind-the-lost-south-park-game/|title=The inside story of the long-lost South Park game|publisher=|accessdate=2 January 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{South Park}} {{Iguana Entertainment}} {{DEFAULTSORT:South Park (Video Game)}} [[Category:1998 video games]] [[Category:Cancelled Dreamcast games]] [[Category:Cancelled Game Boy Color games]] [[Category:First-person shooters]] [[Category:Nintendo 64 games]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games]] [[Category:Video games based on South Park]] [[Category:Video games developed in Hungary]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]]

{{Use Australian English|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox building | name = Spare Parts Puppet Theatre | native_name = | former_names = State Shipping Service Office
Fremantle Art Gallery | alternate_names = | image = WTFr Nov 2011 gnangarra-37.jpg | alt = | caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = Spare Parts Puppet Theatre | landlord = [[Department of Culture and the Arts]] | location = | address = 1–9 [[Short Street, Fremantle|Short Street]] | location_town = [[Fremantle, Western Australia]] | location_country = [[Australia]] | iso_region = | longitude = | latitude = | start_date = | completion_date = 1921 | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | height = | diameter = | floor_count = | floor_area = | main_contractor = | architect = | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | awards = | url = http://www.sppt.asn.au/ | references = }} The '''Spare Parts Puppet Theatre''' is located at 1–9 Short Street, [[Fremantle, Western Australia]], in [[Pioneer Park, Fremantle|Pioneer Park]], opposite the [[Fremantle railway station]]. ==History== The building was constructed as a commercial building in 1921. It is a two storey [[limestone]] building with a [[corrugated iron]] roof, constructed in the [[Federation architecture#Styles|Federation Free Classical]] style of architecture. The building was used as the [[State Shipping Service of Western Australia|State Shipping Service]] Office. In 1975 it was vested in the [[City of Fremantle]] and in September 1978 it was officially opened as the Fremantle Art Gallery.{{Cite web| author1=Fremantle Art Gallery | title=Selection from the City of Fremantle collection, official opening exhibition, September 10 – October 9, 1978 | publication-date=1978 | publisher=The Gallery | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/9595343 | accessdate=28 December 2011 }} In 1988 it was refurbished to specifically accommodate the Spare Parts Puppet Theatre. ==Heritage value== The building is listed on the [[City of Fremantle]]'s Municipal Heritage List.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fremantle.wa.gov.au/files/8a085022-191f-4713-80ee-9f7a00b8119c/Heritage_Areas_LPS4_2011.pdf|format=pdf|title=City of Fremantle Heritage List|publisher=[[City of Fremantle]]|accessdate=28 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319121238/http://www.fremantle.wa.gov.au/files/8a085022-191f-4713-80ee-9f7a00b8119c/Heritage_Areas_LPS4_2011.pdf|archivedate=19 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} ==Current use== Spare Parts Puppet Theatre was founded by Peter Wilson,{{Cite book|title=The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Asia|author1=Rubin, Don|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=1998|volume=5|page=84|isbn=978-0-415-05933-6}} Cathryn Robinson and Beverley Campbell-Jackson in 1981,{{Cite book|title=Theatre Australia (un)limited: Australian theatre since the 1950s|author1=Milne, Geoffery|year=2004|publisher=Rodopi|page=358|isbn=90-420-0930-6}} as part of an artist-in-residency program initiated by the WA Institute of Technology (now [[Curtin University of Technology]]). The company's first project was a puppet adaptation of [[Christopher Marlowe]]'s ''[[Doctor Faustus (play)|Doctor Faustus]]'' for the 1981 [[Perth International Arts Festival|Festival of Perth]]. For the first seven years, the company was a touring company, but in 1998 it acquired the Fremantle Art Gallery as a permanent home. From 1997 through to 2001, the company was under the artistic direction of [[Noriko Nishimoto]]. In 2001 Philip Mitchell was appointed the company's new artistic director. In April 2008 the Spare Parts Puppet Theatre hosted the 20th [[UNIMA]] (Union Internationals de la Marlonette) World Puppetry Festival and Congress. ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==Further reading== * {{Cite book | author1=Webb, Laurie | title=Collection of Six Articles on Puppetry and Puppet Companies in Australia | journal=Lowdown | publication-date=February 1999 | volume=21 | issue=1 | pages=3–5,8–9,12–18 | issn=0158-099X }} * {{Cite web | title=Spare Parts Puppet Theatre : Programs and Related Material collected by the National Library of Australia |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]] | publication-date=1999 | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/14924565 | accessdate=28 December 2011 }} {{Commons category|Spare Parts Puppet Theatre}} {{Cinemas in Western Australia}} {{coord|-32.0533|115.7451|display=title|format=dms}} [[Category:Landmarks in Perth, Western Australia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1921]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Perth, Western Australia]] [[Category:Theatres in Australia]] [[Category:Puppetry]] [[Category:Theatre companies in Australia]] [[Category:Pioneer Park, Fremantle]] {{theatre-struct-stub}}

{{Infobox recurring event | name = StudentCam | native_name = | logo = | logo_caption = | image = | imagesize = frameless | caption = | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency =Annual | location =United States, Guam | years_active =2006-present | first = | last = | participants = Middle school students (grades 6-8)
High school students (grades 9-12) | genre =Documentary filmmaking competition | budget = | patron =C-SPAN | website =[http://www.studentcam.org StudentCam.org] | footnotes = }} '''StudentCam''' is an annual [[competition]] selecting the best [[Documentary film|video documentaries]] on current-affairs topics created by [[Middle school|middle]] and [[high school]] students. It is sponsored by the [[Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network]]'s (C-SPAN) Classroom project.{{cite web |url=http://www.school-video-news.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=572:cspan-studentcam-2010&catid=49:competitions&Itemid=117 |title=C-SPAN StudentCam 2010 |author=Amanda Lynn Porter |work=School Video News.com |publisher=School Video Systems, Inc |accessdate=11 November 2010}} All winning documentaries are available to watch on the StudentCam website. The top 25 winners are interviewed for television broadcast and have their documentaries aired on C-SPAN.{{cite news |title=Students tune in through film |author=Patrick Gavin |newspaper=USA Today |date=17 May 2006 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/2006-05-17-cspan-student-films_x.htm |accessdate=12 November 2010}} ==Overview== The aim of the competition, as stated by C-SPAN, is to provide an opportunity for young people to voice their opinions on current events.{{cite news |title=C-SPAN lets area students have a voice |author=Michael H. Hodges |newspaper=The Detroit News |date=24 November 2009}} Middle and high school students can compete alone or in groups of up to three, entering a video documentary between 5 and 8 minutes in length, which presents more than one side to the selected topic and includes related C-SPAN programming. Each year a new theme related to current affairs is provided, and competitors must use this as the basis for their entry.{{cite news |title=Behind the Lens: Local teen filmmakers tackle C-SPAN’s StudentCam Documentary Contest |author=Anne Pick |newspaper=The Source Weekly |date=13 January 2010|url=http://www.tsweekly.com/news/features/behind-the-lens-local-teen-filmmakers-tackle-c-spans-studentcam-documentary-contest.html |accessdate=11 November 2010}} Subjects have ranged from [[video game violence]] to [[illegal immigration]]. [[File:StudentCam winners 2010.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Eighth grade students from [[McKinley Middle Charter School]] in [[Racine, Wisconsin]] discuss their 2010 grand prize-winning video, ''I’ve Got the Power''.]]The deadline for entries is in January each year{{cite news |title=C-SPAN Student documentary contest open |newspaper=The State Journal |date=17 October 2009 |url=http://www.state-journal.com/news/simple_article/4691111 |accessdate=12 November 2010}} and the StudentCam winners are announced live on C-SPAN's ''[[Washington Journal]]'', usually in March each year.{{cite web |url=http://www.timewarnercable.com/northeast/about/inthenewsdetails.ashx?PRID=2518&MarketID=152 |title=Latham, NY Student Wins Third Prize in C-SPAN's National StudentCam Video Competition |date=24 March 2009 |work=TimeWarnerCable.com |accessdate=11 November 2010}} Following the announcement, the top 25 entries are shown on C-SPAN,{{cite news |title=Rep. Walz Congratulates C-SPAN Documentary Contest Winners |newspaper=US Fed News |date=7 May 2007}} one documentary each weekday morning, accompanied by a telephone interview with the student filmmakers. All of the winning documentaries are available on the StudentCam website. The winning filmmakers receive cash prizes typically totaling $50,000, with the grand prize-winner receiving $5,000, in addition to being featured on C-SPAN. {{As of|2010}}, 75 entries each year are chosen as prize-winners, and 11 teacher awards are given to teachers who incorporate the competition into their classes. The sponsor of the StudentCam competition is C-SPAN Classroom, a free membership organization providing teachers with C-SPAN materials for classes and research. Promotion of the competition is often supplemented by local cable providers.{{cite news |title=C-SPAN promoting student documentaries |author=Charles Lussier |newspaper=The Advocate |date=10 October 2009}} ==History== The StudentCam competition developed from a documentary competition called CampaignCam, run by C-SPAN during the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential campaign]] as a way of including students' views about the election. The StudentCam forerunner won a Beacon Award in 2005, conferred by the cable industry for excellence in communications and public affairs.{{cite news |title=2005 Beacon Awards: Education: Full Campaign/Single Activity; Cable Network III |author= |work=Multichannel News |date=9 May 2005 }} In 2006, StudentCam was launched by C-SPAN, adding a requirement that students include relevant C-SPAN programming. The 2009 competition received the most entries to date, when nearly 2,000 students from 41 states, the [[District of Columbia]] and [[Guam]] submitted a total of 921 submissions.{{cite news |title=C-SPAN surprises PMS students with award for StudentCam video entry |author=Emily West |newspaper=Pleasanton Weekly |date=20 March 2009 |url=http://www.pleasantonweekly.com/news/show_story.php?id=1535 |accessdate=12 November 2010}} The grand prize winner of the competition, Sawyer Bowman, a 10th grade student from [[Davidson, North Carolina]] was congratulated by President [[Barack Obama]] via a specially-recorded video message. A first-prize winner in the 2010 competition, Matthew Shimura, met [[First Lady]] [[Michelle Obama]] at the [[White House]] in April 2010 during a [[town hall meeting]] for her "Let's Move!" initiative, to talk about fighting childhood obesity, which was the subject of Matthew's video.{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2010/04/michelle-obama-obesity.html |title=Michelle Obama explains how the First Family fights fat; Now, yours can, too |author=Andrew Malcolm |date=7 April 2010 |work=L.A. Times Top of the Ticket |publisher= |accessdate=12 November 2010}} ===Grand prize winners=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ ! Year!!Students!!Film title |- | 2006 || Anthony Hernandez and Dustin Gillard || ''Anywhere USA'' |- | 2007 || Zach Chastain, Bryan Cink and Ryan Kelly || ''Jupiter or Bust: The El Sol Solution''{{cite web |url=http://www.eschoolnews.com/2007/05/08/c-span-announces-winners-in-2007-quot-studentcam-quot-a-political-student-video-competition/ |title=C-SPAN Announces Winners in 2007 "StudentCam," a Political Student Video Competition |date=8 May 2007 |work=eSchoolNews.com |publisher=eSchool Media Inc. |accessdate=16 November 2010}} |- | 2008 || Scott Mitchell and Nick Poss || ''Leaving Religion at the Door''{{cite news |title=C-SPAN's StudentCam Winner: Leaving Religion at the Door? |author=Alexander Carpenter |newspaper=Spectrum Magazine |date=19 February 2008 |url=http://www.spectrummagazine.org/node/365 |accessdate=12 November 2010}} |- | 2009 || Sawyer Bowman || ''Cancer. It's Personal'' |- | 2010 || Madison Richards, Samantha Noll and Lauren Nixon || ''I've Got the Power''{{cite news |title=McKinley students win national documentary competition |author=Lindsey Fiori |newspaper=The Journal Times |date=10 March 2010 |url=http://www.journaltimes.com/news/local/article_b1c7fa7c-2bdf-11df-a942-001cc4c03286.html |accessdate=16 November 2010}} |- | 2011 || Carl Colglazier || ''The Great Compromise''{{cite web |url=http://www.studentcam.org/StudentCam_2011_Winner_Announcement_Release.pdf |title= C‐SPAN Announces Winners of 2011 StudentCam Video Documentary Competition |date=9 March 2011 |work=studentcam.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=19 September 2011}} |- | 2012 || Matthew Shimura || ''The Constitution and the Camps: Due Process and the Japanese-American Internment'{{cite web |url=http://www.studentcam.org/Winners12.htm |title=C-SPAN StudentCam 2012 Winners |date=7 March 2012 |work=studentcam.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=28 November 2014}} |- | 2013 || Josh Stokes || ''Unemployment in America''{{cite web |url=http://www.studentcam.org/Winners13.htm |title=C-SPAN StudentCam 2013 - Winning Videos |date=6 March 2012 |work=studentcam.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=28 November 2014}} |- | 2014 || Emma Larson, Michaela Capps, and Sarah Highducheck || ''Earth First, Fracking Second''{{cite web |url=http://www.studentcam.org/Winners14.htm |title=C-SPAN StudentCam 2014 - Winners |date=5 March 2012 |work=studentcam.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=28 November 2014}} |- | 2015 || Anna Gilligan, Katie Demos and Michael Lozovoy || ''The Artificial Wage''{{cite web |url=http://www.studentcam.org/winners15.htm |title=StudentCam 2015 Competition - Winners |date=4 March 2015 |work=studentcam.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=5 February 2017}} |- | 2016 || Olivia Hurd || ''Up to Our Necks''{{cite web |url=http://www.studentcam.org/winners16.htm |title=StudentCam 2016 Competition - Winners |date=9 March 2016 |work=studentcam.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=5 February 2017}} |- | 2017 || Ava and Mia Lazar || ''The Tempest-Tossed''{{cite web |url=http://www.studentcam.org/winners17.htm |title=StudentCam 2017 Competition - Winners |date=8 March 2017 |work=studentcam.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=26 March 2017}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.studentcam.org StudentCam] official website {{C-SPAN navbox}} [[Category:Competitions]] [[Category:Film competitions]] [[Category:C-SPAN]] [[Category:Education in the United States]] [[Category:2006 establishments in the United States]]

'''Takenoko-zoku''' (竹の子族, lit. "[[bamboo]] shoot tribe") describes a type of dance group active from the mid-1970s to the mid-1980s in [[Tokyo]], especially in [[Harajuku]]. The teenagers, mainly girls but often with one boy leading, were colorfully dressed and danced in a distinctive style on the sidewalk to music from stereos.<ref name=Okubo>{{cite web|last1=Okubo|first1=Miki|title=Harajuku – District for Anti-fashion|url=http://fashion.semiotix.org/2014/02/harajuku-district-for-anti-fashion/|website=SemiotiX – Design, Style and Fashion|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> To an extent, they were precursors to the [[gyaru]] groups that would eventually arise in the 90s.<ref name=Okubo/>
A performance of a takenoko-zoku group can be seen in [[Chris Marker]]'s film ''[[Sans Soleil]]''.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080317023954/http://blog.q-taro.com/places-in-tokyo/takenoko-zoku/ Takenoko-zoku photos]
[[Category:Performing arts in Japan]] [[Category:Shibuya]]

{{Infobox zoo |zoo_name=Tama Zoo |logo= |logo_width= |logo_caption= |image=Tama-zoo.jpg |image_caption=The zoo's entrance |image_width=250px |date_opened=1958 |location=[[Hino, Tokyo]], [[Japan]] |area={{Convert|52|ha|abbr=on}} |coordinates={{Coord|35|39|N|139|24|E|display=it|region:JP-13_type:landmark}} |num_species= |num_animals= |exhibits = |members=[[Japanese Association of Zoos and Aquariums|JAZA]] }} The {{nihongo|'''Tama Zoological Park'''|多摩動物公園|Tama Dōbutsukōen|'''Tama Zoo''' for short}} is a [[zoo]], owned by the government of [[Tokyo Metropolis]], and located in [[Hino, Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. The Tama Zoo was opened on May 5, 1958, originally as a {{nihongo|branch|分園||satellite facility}} of the [[Ueno Zoo]]. The zoo aims to use its large site – 52 ha, compared to the 14.3 ha of the Ueno Zoo – to show its animals moving in a more free and natural environment.
== Major attractions==
===Asian Garden/Zone=== ; [[Orangutan]] Skywalk : Connects orangutan enclosures with towers and wire ropes. Total length of 150 metres. ; Raptor Enclosure : A large dome enclosure that enables birds of prey such as [[white-tailed eagle]]s and [[golden eagle]]s to be viewed flying freely. ; [[Malayan Tapir]] Enclosure : Enables visitors to view Malayan tapirs swimming via a glass window. ; [[Mole (animal)|Mole]] House : A man-made mole [[burrow]] made of glass-covered earth and metal tunnels. Also exhibits the ''Sorex minutissimus hawkeri'', a subspecies of the [[Eurasian least shrew]] that is the smallest [[mammal]] found in [[Japan]]. ; Asian Swampland : Reproduces the habitats of the [[Indian rhinoceros]], [[Asian water buffalo]], and various [[wading birds]].
===African Garden/Zone=== ; Lion Bus : Enables visitors to view [[lion]]s in a [[safari]] atmosphere. ; Savannah : A large enclosure featuring [[giraffe]]s, [[Grevy's zebra]]s, [[scimitar-horned oryx]], [[ostrich]]es, and [[pelican]]s. ; [[African Elephant]] : The World's Largest Land Animal, [[African Elephant]]s can be shown in African Garden. ; [[Chimpanzee]] Forest : Includes a 15-metre-high tower and vending machine, to showcase the athletic and mental abilities of the [[Common chimpanzee|chimpanzee]].
===Australian Garden/Zone=== ; Koala House : Exhibits [[marsupial]]s such as [[sugar glider]]s and [[common ringtail possum|ringtail possum]]s, in addition to [[koala]]s, [[wombat]]s and [[emu]]s.
===Insectarium=== ; Main Building : A building modeled after a [[dragonfly]], which contains exhibits relating to the life of insects. ; Butterfly House : A large greenhouse that visitors can enter to observe various species of [[butterfly|butterflies]] and [[grasshopper]]s all year round.
==Other animals== *[[Cheetah]] *[[Serval]] *[[Golden Takin]] *[[Snow Leopard]] *[[Red kangaroo]] *[[Asian elephant]] *[[Lesser panda]] *[[Oriental stork]] *[[Japanese macaque]] *[[Sun bear]] *[[Flamingo]] *A [[common wombat]] named [http://www001.upp.so-net.ne.jp/womland/ Chewbacca]
==Access== [[Tama-Dōbutsukōen Station]] on the [[Keiō Dōbutsuen Line]] and the [[Tama Toshi Monorail Line]] is in front of the park's gate.
==External links== {{Commons category|Tama Zoo}} * [http://www.tokyo-zoo.net/english/tama/main.html Official site (English)] * [http://www.tokyo-zoo.net/zoo/tama/index.html Official site (Japanese)]
{{Zoos of Japan}}

{{Infobox television | show_name = The Carrie Diaries | image = The Carrie Diaries intertitle.png | alt = The words "The Carrie Diaries" written against a black written in bright pink letters with a small heart above the letter 'i' | genre = [[Teen drama]]
[[Comedy-drama]]
[[Period drama]] | camera = | runtime = 60 minutes | based_on = {{Based on|''[[The Carrie Diaries]]''|[[Candace Bushnell]]}} | developer = [[Amy B. Harris]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[AnnaSophia Robb]] * [[Austin Butler]] * [[Ellen Wong]] * [[Katie Findlay]] * [[Stefania Owen]] * [[Brendan Dooling]] * [[Chloe Bridges]] * [[Freema Agyeman]] * [[Matt Letscher]] * Lindsey Gort}} | narrated = AnnaSophia Robb | executive_producer = {{plainlist| * [[Miguel Arteta]] * [[Candace Bushnell]] * Len Goldstein * Amy B. Harris * [[Stephanie Savage]] * [[Josh Schwartz]] }} | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | composer = [[Mark Mothersbaugh]] | country = United States | language = English | company = {{plainlist| * [[Fake Empire Productions]] * A.B. Baby Productions * [[Warner Bros. Television]] }} | distributor = [[Warner Bros. Television Distribution]] | location = | network = [[The CW]] | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 26 | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|1|14}} | last_aired = {{Start date|2014|1|31}} | picture_format = | list_episodes = List of The Carrie Diaries episodes | preceded_by = ''[[Sex and the City]]'' (1998–2004) | website = }} '''''The Carrie Diaries''''' is an American [[teen drama|teen]] [[comedy-drama]] television series that aired for two seasons on [[The CW]] from January 14, 2013, to January 31, 2014. It is a [[prequel]] to the [[HBO]] television series ''[[Sex and the City]]'' and based on the [[The Carrie Diaries|2010 book of the same name]] by [[Candace Bushnell]]. The first season focuses on [[Carrie Bradshaw]] ([[AnnaSophia Robb]]) during her junior year of [[high school]] in 1984 as she explores life in [[New York City]] while interning at a law firm office, and also secretly working at a magazine company, while the second season focuses more on her expanding life in the city as well as the lives of her friends and boyfriend. The pilot was picked up by The CW to a series order of 13 episodes in May 2012.{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/11/08/carrie-diaries-date|title='Carrie Diaries' gets CW premiere date|last=Hibberd|first=James|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=November 8, 2012|accessdate=November 8, 2012}} Four months into the first season, the network renewed ''The Carrie Diaries'' for a second season, which premiered in October 2013.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/05/09/nikita-and-the-carrie-diaries-renewed-by-the-cw|title='Nikita' Renewed For A Short (Final?) 4th Season & 'The Carrie Diaries' Renewed For 2nd Season|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|work=TV by the Numbers|date=May 9, 2013|accessdate=May 10, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2013/06/24/the-cw-premiere-dates-2013-fall|title=Fall TV Premiere Dates: The CW Once Again Opens Its Season in October|last=Mittovich|first=Matt|work=TV Line|date=June 24, 2013|accessdate=June 24, 2013}} In May 2014, The CW canceled the series after two seasons.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/05/08/carrie-diaries-tomorrow-people-star-crossed-cancelled-by-the-cw/261849/|title='Carrie Diaries', 'Tomorrow People' & 'Star-Crossed' Canceled by The CW|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|work=TV by the Numbers|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=May 8, 2014}} ==Cast and characters== ===Main cast=== * [[AnnaSophia Robb]] as [[Carrie Bradshaw]]; The protagonist and voice-over narrator of the series. She is a 16-year-old high school student living in the fictional town of Castlebury, [[Connecticut]], who dreams of being a famous writer. Carrie's mother recently died from cancer and as a result, Carrie's younger sister, Dorrit, is more rebellious than ever, and their father, Tom, is overwhelmed with the responsibility of suddenly having to care for two teenage girls on his own. Instead of attending school on one day during the week, Carrie takes an internship at a law firm in New York City which she relishes as a stepping stone in her quest to leave her small town behind her. She left this position to work for Larissa Loughlin at ''[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]'' magazine. Towards the end of high school, Larissa offers Carrie a full-time job at the magazine, which she accepts over going to NYU. Unfortunately, when Larissa is fired, so is Carrie. She decides to stay in New York, rather than going to Malibu with Sebastian. In the Season 2 finale, she moves into Larissa's apartment with Samantha. * [[Austin Butler]] as Sebastian Kydd; The new kid at Castlebury High School and Carrie's love interest. Sebastian moves to Castlebury after getting kicked out of his old high school for having sex with his art history teacher. He lives with his divorced mother who is never around. He and Carrie date during the second half of the first season, before breaking up (after a fight resulting in Sebastian kissing Maggie, Carrie's best friend). They are constantly going back and forth from a couple to singles and back, which is much more known as an on and off relationship, but it is clear that they both have feelings for each other. At the end of Season 2, Sebastian moves to Malibu to run his company, and it seems that he and Carrie may have broken up. *[[Ellen Wong]] as Jill "Mouse" Chen; Jill is Carrie's nerdy and sweet best friend from high school and the ex-girlfriend of a college guy she still loves, and lost her virginity to. They broke up because both of their grades were getting low, because they were only focusing on eachother. In school, she is an academic overachiever who is said to be under pressure and driven to be the best at everything by her stern parents. Mouse accepts an offer to go to Harvard towards the end of Season 2. *[[Katie Findlay]] as Maggie Landers; Carrie's best friend, and Walt's sexually active ex-girlfriend. She is a sarcastic and self-assured underachieving student who barely passes her classes and is said to have an unhappy home life where her parents neglect and ignore her, who are not able to pay for her college life. She cares about Carrie, and will sacrifice her own happiness for Carrie's. Maggie is proposed to by Pete in the last episode of Season 2, and she accepts. * [[Stefania LaVie Owen]] as Dorrit Bradshaw; Carrie's troubled, 14-year-old, rebellious younger sister. She openly resents Carrie for being close with their mother, and for not having more time with her. She is rebelling by dyeing her hair and wearing too much eye make-up as well as seeing a guy older that Carrie called Miller. * [[Brendan Dooling]] as Walter "Walt" Reynolds; Carrie's other best friend. He is Maggie's ex-boyfriend. He doesn't know that she is cheating on him with a cop. In the ending of the first episode, it's implied that Walt is [[Closeted|secretly gay]]. In later episodes it is clear he is confused about his sexuality, he even sparks an interest in a man named Bennet Wilcox (an employee at Interview Magazine). At the end of the first season he and Maggie break up, and she (as well as the rest of the group) finds out about his homosexuality. In season 2 he begins dating Bennett and his mom sees a picture of them in a local newspaper and kicks him out. He lives at Carrie's for 3 episodes before being scared off by the potential to get AIDS, breaking up with Bennett and moving back in with his parents, denying his sexuality again. By the end of Season 2, his parents finally accept Walt's homosexuality. * [[Chloe Bridges]] as Donna LaDonna; The school's most popular girl, and the [[Queen bee (sociology)|leader]] of a [[clique]]s called "[[Adolescent cliques|The Jens]]", which is made up of all of the school's shallow and narcissistic "mean girls". She was Carrie's chief rival in the first season and also had a crush on Walt. When she found out that Walt was gay, she protected his secret by telling the whole school that they had sex, and pretending that they were dating for real. She is currently frenemies with Carrie. * [[Freema Agyeman]] as Larissa Loughlin; A hip, British, cutting-edge style editor at ''Interview'' magazine and party girl, who acts as Carrie's mentor in New York City, while she is working at the law firm. It is later revealed that Larissa is an African princess who ran away from her family and found financial support from a British lord before moving to America. Carrie introduces Larissa to Harlan, her father Tom's friend, and Larissa and Harlan get married in the Season 2 finale. * [[Matt Letscher]] as Tom Bradshaw; Carrie's overprotective father. He loosens up a bit as the series progresses. When Carrie chooses a job at Interview over going to NYU, Tom disapproves and cuts her off financially. In the Season 2 finale, Tom and Carrie mend their relationship when she tells him that she will stay in New York and support herself. * Lindsey Gort as [[Samantha Jones (Sex and the City)|Samantha Jones]]; Donna's brash and outgoing older cousin whom Carrie befriends. She is part of Manhattan's music scene, where she used to work at a bar as a bouncer. Samantha and Carrie move in together at the end of Season 2.{{cite web|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2013/08/carrie-diaries-season-2-scoop-how-will-carrie-bradshaw-meet-samantha-jones.html|title='Carrie Diaries' Season 2 scoop: How will Carrie Bradshaw meet Samantha Jones?|last=Bucksbaum|first=Sydney|work=Zap2It|date=August 15, 2013|accessdate=February 2, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/441002/the-carrie-diaries-casts-samantha-jones-for-season-2|title=''The Carrie Diaries'' Casts Samantha Jones For Season 2|last=Bricker|first=Tierney|work=E! Online|date=July 20, 2013|accessdate=July 20, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2013/07/20/the-carrie-diaries-casts-lindsey-gort-as-samantha-jones|title=''The Carrie Diaries'' Scoop: Meet Young Samantha!|last=Slezak|first=Michael|work=TV Line|date=July 20, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013}} ===Recurring cast=== * Josh Salatin as Simon Byrnes, a former local policeman and Maggie's former [[Casual sex|casual]] [[sexual partner]]. Maggie ended up pregnant with Simon's child but lost it when she experienced complications. He is fired by Maggie's father when he finds out. * [[Jake Robinson (actor)|Jake Robinson]] as Bennet Wilcox, Larissa's co-worker and Walt's former boyfriend. Walt broke up with him when he realised that he wants all the things that gay people can't have, after a health scare with AIDS. Towards the end of second season Walt decides that he cannot live a lie and reconciles with Bennet, realising that he missed him. * [[Scott Cohen (actor)|Scott Cohen]] as Harlan Silver, Tom's friend who encourages him to begin dating, who is also Larissa's fiance. * [[Nadia Dajani]] as Deb, Tom's ex-girlfriend. * R.J. Brown as Thomas West, Mouse's academic rival and former boyfriend. The two broke up after West explained that he was tired of competing with Mouse after she got accepted in Harvard. *Whitney Vance and Alexandra Miller as the Jens, Donna LaDonna's two minions. They follow her around in explosions of neon doing whatever their leader tells them to. * [[Evan Crooks]] as Miller, Dorrit's former boyfriend who works at the Record store. * [[Chris Wood (actor)|Chris Wood]] as Adam Weaver (4 episodes), a guy who Carrie meets while trying to get an interview for the magazine, took her virginity, and is currently her ex. * Giullian Yao Gioiello as Scott, Dorrit's friend who later becomes her boyfriend. They meet at the Bradshaw house party. He eventually becomes her boyfriend near the end of Season 2 upon being tricked to go to prom with him. ==Production== ===Development=== In September 2011, it was officially announced that The CW was moving forward with a television series as a [[prequel]] to the original series, based on ''The Carrie Diaries''. The project is produced by ''[[Gossip Girl]]'' producers [[Josh Schwartz]] and [[Stephanie Savage]]. Former ''[[Sex and the City]]'' writer [[Amy B. Harris]] penned the adaptation.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/09/update-carries-diaries-now-officially-at-cw-with-gossip-girl-producers-on-board|title='The Carrie Diarires' Now Officially At CW With 'Gossip Girl' Producers On Board|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=September 11, 2011|accessdate=July 15, 2012}} On January 18, 2012, The CW ordered a pilot of ''The Carrie Diaries''. The project will continue to be helmed by executive producers Josh Schwartz, Stephanie Savage, Len Goldstein and [[Candace Bushnell]].{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/01/18/carrie-diaries|title=CW orders 'Sex and the City' prequel pilot, more|last=Hibberd|first=James|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=January 18, 2012|accessdate=September 6, 2012}} On May 11, 2012, the pilot was picked up to series.{{cite web|title=CW's 'Carrie Diaries,' 'Arrow,' 'Cult,' 'First Cut,' 'Beauty and the Beast' Ordered to Series|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/cw-carrie-diaries-arrow-cult-first-cut-beauty-beast-323580|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=May 12, 2012|last1=Goldberg|first1=Lesley|last2=Rose|first2=Lacey|date=May 11, 2012}} On May 9, 2013, The CW renewed ''The Carrie Diaries'' for a second season. It received an order for 13 episodes.{{cite web|title=The CW Confirms "Carrie Diaries," "Beauty and the Beast" Episode Orders; Other Post-Upfront Notes|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2013/05/16/the-cw-confirms-carrie-diaries-beauty-and-the-beast-episode-orders-other-post-upfront-notes-417312/10382/|publisher=Thefutoncritic.com|accessdate=May 18, 2013|date=May 16, 2013}} ===Casting=== On February 15, 2012, the series' first role was cast. [[Stefania Owen]] has landed the part of Carrie Bradshaw's 14-year-old sister Dorrit. She's described as rebelling in the most obvious of ways: dyeing her hair, getting arrested, acting out. Dorrit is desperate for attention and willing to get it any way she can.{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/02/15/carrie-diaries-stefania-owen|title='Carrie Diaries' casting scoop: Bradshaw's sister is... – EXCLUSIVE|last=Hibberd|first=James|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=February 15, 2012|accessdate=February 28, 2012}} On February 27, 2012, it was announced that [[AnnaSophia Robb]] had won the role of the young Carrie Bradshaw.{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2012/02/annasophia-robb-lands-role-as-young-carrie-bradshaw/1|title=AnnaSophia Robb lands role as young Carrie Bradshaw|last=Oldenburg|first=Ann|work=USA Today|date=February 27, 2012|accessdate=February 28, 2012}} On February 28, [[Katie Findlay]] and [[Ellen Wong]] joined her. Wong will play Carrie's best friend in high school, Jill Chen. Also known as 'The Mouse', Jill is said to be intelligent and loyal. Findlay will star in the project as Carrie's oldest friend Maggie Landers, the police chief's daughter. Whereas Carrie is beginning to explore Manhattan, Maggie has no desire to leave her town.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a368234/sex-and-the-city-prequel-casts-katie-findlay-ellen-wong.html|title='Sex and the City' prequel casts Katie Findlay, Ellen Wong|last=Wightman|first=Catriona|work=Digital Spy|date=February 28, 2012|accessdate=February 28, 2012}} On March 2, 2012, [[Deadline Hollywood|Deadline]] reported that [[Austin Butler]] has been cast as the male lead. Butler will play Sebastian Kydd, a brooding heartthrob and ultimate insider who always plays the outsider. His presence at Carrie's school will shake things up in a big way.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/sarah-wright-and-amy-huberman-land-comedy-pilot-leads|title=Sarah Wright & Amy Huberman Get Leads In NBC Pilots, Austin Butler In 'Carrie Diaries'|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 2, 2012|accessdate=March 3, 2012}} On March 4, 2012, Deadline announced that [[Freema Agyeman]] has been cast in the pilot as Larissa, a hip, cutting-edge editor and party girl who works at ''[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]'' magazine and is Carrie's mentor.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/billy-burke-in-revolution-david-harbour-in-midnight-sun-among-pilot-cast-additions|title=Billy Burke In 'Revolution', David Harbour In 'Midnight Sun' Among Pilot Cast Additions|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 4, 2012|accessdate=March 6, 2012}} On the same day, [[Brendan Dooling]], who originally auditioned for the role of Sebastian,{{cite web |last=Etkin |first=Jaimie |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/08/carrie-diaries-finale-brendan-dooling_n_3040536.html |title='Carrie Diaries' Finale: Brendan Dooling Previews What's To Come For Walt |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=April 8, 2013 |accessdate=July 28, 2013}} joined the cast as Walt, Carrie's gay friend. On March 9, 2012, Deadline reported that [[Matt Letscher]] had been cast as Carrie's father.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/carrie-bradshaw-gets-a-father-cuba-gooding-gets-a-wife-in-pilot-castings|title=Carrie Bradshaw Gets A Father, Cuba Gooding Gets A Wife In Pilot Castings|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 9, 2012|accessdate=March 10, 2012}} On March 14, 2012, it was announced that [[Chloe Bridges]] had been cast as Carrie's nemesis Donna LaDonna.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/pilots-revolution-baby-big-shot-carrie-diaries-add-regulars|title=Pilots 'Revolution', 'Baby Big Shot' & 'Carrie Diaries' Add Regulars|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 14, 2012|accessdate=March 15, 2012}} On July 20, 2013, [[E! News]] reported that actress Lindsey Gort was cast as [[Samantha Jones (Sex and the City)|Samantha Jones]] for the second season. English model [[Poppy Delevingne]] also auditioned for the role.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Recn0KNh_nE|title=Poppy Delevingne Samantha Jones audition}} After the show's cancellation, showrunner Amy B. Harris revealed that had the show been renewed for a third season, [[Miranda Hobbes]] would have been introduced as Mouse's roommate at Harvard.{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/540322/the-carries-diaries-canceled-boss-reveals-how-carrie-would-ve-met-miranda-and-more|title=''The Carrie Diaries'' Canceled: Boss Reveals How Carrie Would've Met Miranda and More|last=Bricker|first=Tierney|last2=Santos|first2=Kristin|work=E! '''[[The Carrie Diaries (season 2)|Season 2]]''' ! span style="font-weight:normal;line-height:100%"| Fridays 8:00 pm ! 13 | style="font-size:11px;line-height:110%" style="text-align:center"|{{Start date|2013|10|25}} ! 0.78 | style="font-size:11px;line-height:110%" style="text-align:center"|{{End date|2014|1|31}} ! 0.86 ! #172{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/05/tv-season-series-rankings-2013-full-list-2-733762/|title=Full 2013-2014 TV Season Series Rankings|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=May 22, 2014|accessdate=April 30, 2015}} ! 0.82 |- |} == Reception == === Critical response === {{Anchor|Critics}} ''The Carrie Diaries'' has received mixed reviews. [[Metacritic]] gave the first season a score of 57% based on 23 reviews, indicating "mixed or average reviews," based on 23 critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-carrie-diaries|title='The Carrie Diaries' review: Forget about 'Sex and the City' and enjoy The CW's new series|last=|first=|work=Metacritic|date=|accessdate=January 16, 2012}} [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave season 1 a score of 63% based on reviews from 30 critics.https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the-carrie-diaries/s01 Gail Pennington of the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' said "The CW's attempt to capture the magic of ''Sex and the City'' in a prequel, set in 1984, could have gone very wrong. But ''The Carrie Diaries'' is surprisingly right."{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/television/gail-pennington/tv-review-cw-s-carrie-diaries-is-a-charmer/article_db23aa45-f447-5497-92c8-5b96c9c3df84.html|title=TV review: CW's 'Carrie Diaries' is a charmer|last=Pennington|first=Gail|work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=January 14, 2012|accessdate=January 16, 2012}} Marisa LaScala of PopMatters says "The rest of the show goes on to prize sweetness over superficiality."{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/167230-the-carrie-diaries-high-school-origin-story/|title='The Carrie Diaries': High School Origin Story|last=LaScala|first=Marisa|work=PopMatters|date=January 14, 2012|accessdate=January 16, 2012}} Alan Sepinwall of Hitfix describes "The new series succeeds on its own nostalgic terms."{{cite web|url=http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/review-cws-the-carrie-diaries-takes-sex-and-the-city-back-to-the-80s|title=Review: CW's 'The Carrie Diaries' takes 'Sex and the City' back to the '80s|last=Spinwall|first=Alan|work=Hitfix|date=January 14, 2012|accessdate=January 16, 2012}} The second season opened with generally more favorable reviews. ''Rotten Tomatoes'' gave it score 100%, based on 5 reviews,{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the-carrie-diaries/s02|title=The Carrie Diaries: Season 02|date=25 October 2013|publisher=}} and praised the introduction of Lindsey Gort as the iconic ''Sex and the City'' character, Samantha Jones. === Awards and accolades === {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Awards and accolades for ''The Carrie Diaries'' |- ! '''The Stolen Princess''' is a 2018 Ukrainian [[3D film|3D]] animated [[fantasy film]] directed by Oleg Malamuzh and based on a fairy tale [[Ruslan and Lyudmila]] by Russian poet [[Aleksandr Pushkin]]. The film premiere in [[Ukraine]] took place on March 7, 2018.
The film tells about a wandering artist Ruslan who saves princess Mila kidnapped by evil sorcerer Chornomor.<ref name="ufd">{{Cite web|url=http://ufd.ua/films/stolen_princess|title=On the site of the Ukrainian UFD tape prodigy|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170902193858/http://ufd.ua/films/stolen_princess|archivedate=September 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

==Plot==
Two sorcerers, Finn and Shernomore, have an intense magical duel in favor of saving Finn's wife, Meena. Finn gains the upperhand at first, but is defeated by Shernomore who deceives him by stepping on a "force field", and losing all of his powers and youthfullness, which then transfers to Shernomore and transforms Meena into a stone statue in exchange for her power of love as a source of his magic.
In the present day, Ruslan, a wandering artist dreaming to become a knight, is having a small play which he plays the role of Finn and Shernomore, and is written by an eccentric and an aspiring playwright, Lester. In the castle lived a adventurous and kind princess named Meelah. She considers the castle as a hindrance for his father and the King, is forcing her to get married despite she doesn't love whoever he suggests. One night, she sneaks out and she was almost harrased by two men, until Ruslan arrives. He saves Meelah from the two and escape. When the two are alone, Ruslan, afraid of being judged by his status, disguises himself as a knight.
The next day, they share romantic moments as they develop their feelings for each other. Unfortunately, much to Ruslan's surprise and horror, Meelah was kidnapped via a tornado by Shernomore, He tries to pursue Meelah, but fails to do so and knocks himself unconscious. When he gained consciousness, he is confronted by the King, who mistakenly accuses him of harming the princess. He tries to tell the truth, but none of them belived him. Realizing Shernomore is real, he consults Lester and they set off to the cave where a wise cat lives.
The two asks for help on where to find Meelah and reveals to them a magic vortex where they discover a magical place and gives them a pea pod as a "gift". When they reached the cliff, a hamster suddenly steals the pod and they pursue it. But they realized that they are supposed to give it to him and unlocks a dinosaur-like bridge.
Meanwhile, at Shernomore's castle, Meelah awakens at a bed and she tries to escape using a hat that makes the user invisible. Despite Shernomore casting a spell that makes all of the desserts there alive, she manages to defeat these and discovers the other ladies who are victims of Shernomore's evil sorcery.
When the two arrive at the cave, they meet a strange old man who holds a staff similar to a wizard, and asks help on where to find Finn. However, the old man reveals himself to be Finn. But due to him having no contact on the outside world for too long, he is too paranoid to communicate with. With the help of Ruslan's plan, they pretend to be "wizards" who are casting a "spell" to lure him down. Finn, beliving that his powers are restored, tries to stop them. Ruslan and the gang pretend to be dead, only for them to contain Finn. When they got him, Ruslan asks where to find Shernomore and how to stop him, Finn tells them that his castle is made of spiky rocks and the source of his power is in his beard, asking him to cut it off, but no one was able to do that. And he tells Ruslan that he needs a magic sword in order to do that. After asking for the directions on where to find the sword, they locate and it is guarded by a giant knight. The giant challenges Ruslan in exchange for the armor and sword, but Ruslan manages to defeat all of them and they went to Shernomore's castle.
When they got to the castle, they splitted to find Meelah. Ruslan finds Meelah in a different outfit and appearance and tells him that she does not need to rescue her, for she is happy at this place. This breaks Ruslan's heart. Feeling down, he slowly leaves the place. Suddenly, a giant monster attacks them. Lester tries to convince Ruslan to fight, but he's too lonely to do so. The bird gets Meelah's pendant and makes Ruslan realize that he is being deceived by Shernomore and gains courage to fight the monster.
After defeating the monster, they went to the place where Meelah is kept and he and Shernomore engages at a n intense duel. Ruslan is defeated at first, but manages to incapacitate Shernomore by cutting his beard, losing his powers and transforms the stone staues and Finn back to normal. Ruslan tries to escape with Meelah, but they are trapped in the force field the same way as Finn did before. Ruslan sacrifices himself by pushing Meelah out of the trap, leaving him incapacitated. Meelah tries to pull Ruslan out, but is interrupted by the three nights, resulting in Ruslan's soul being zapped from him and leaving him lifeless. Enraged, Meelah fights the three knights and defeats them all (including Shernomore who is tied up).
Meelah mourns for the apparent death of Ruslan and says that she loves him so much. A now-rejuvenated Finn appears and brings back Ruslan to life. The two reunite including Lester and Finn and Meena reunites as well. Ruslan confesses that he is not a real knight, but Meelah accepts this, and tells she still loves him no matter what. Finn conjures up a fireworks display, and they lived happily ever after.
During the credits, Ruslan and Meelah shows being married and living a happy life.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://stolenprincess.com/en/story|title=History|work=The Stolen Princess|accessdate=2018-04-11}}</ref>
==Budget==
The film is co-financed by Ukrainian State Film Agency: its share is 19.5 million UAH (total production cost of the film is 95.2 million UAH).
==Production==
On January 30, 2013 producer Egor Olesov informed about the development of [[Ruslan and Lyudmila]] project based on a [[fairy tale]] poem with the same title by Aleksandr Pushkin. In September 2013, press service of FILM.UA Group announced the start of film production, and later the protagonists and synopsis for [[Ruslan and Lyudmila]] were presented with the film itself announced as 2D animation; later, however, the concept changed, and a decision was made to create a 3D animated film.
Hollywood consultants helped with developing the characters. According to the authors of the film, [[Ruslan and Lyudmila]] was made in English and then dubbed in Ukrainian. As Olesov says, Hollywood celebrities will be involved in English dubbing, and in [[Ukraine]], popular local actors will lend their voices to the film. For the international market, the film was given another title, ''The Stolen Princess''.
In December 2015, the script and characters’ stories were finalized; animation of approved scenes was completed.
==Release==
=== International Distribution===
''The Stolen Princess'' became the first project in the line of theatrically animated premieres from Animagrad, which also includes Mavka. The Forest Song (2018), Snow Republic (2019), and Roksolana and Suleiman (2021). According to the company director, Animagrad plans to release one animated feature per year, both for local Ukrainian and international distribution.
In February 2015 at the European film market during [[Berlin International Film Festival]], the rights to film distribution were sold to [[Israel]] and [[South Korea]]; in May 2016 at Marché du Film of [[Cannes International Film Festival]], to France, French-speaking territories, [[Bulgaria]], [[Iran]], and [[Poland]]. On December 10, 2016, The Hollywood Reporter informed that the film after its presentation a month before at the American film market was sold to China, (Germany), [[Austria]], [[Switzerland]], [[Lithuania]], [[Latvia]], [[Estonia]], North Africa, and the Middle East. It was also announced that sales to some other territories were pending.<ref name="hollywoodreporter">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/afm-stolen-princess-sells-china-954618|title=AFM: Ukranian Animated Film 'The Stolen Princess' Sells to China|author=Nick Holdsworth|publisher=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}</ref>
On March 13–16, 2017 in Hong Kong, FILMART took place, which is an annual film and TV content market. The FILM.UA Group stand presented projects of Animagrad studio, including ''The Stolen Princess''. On the penultimate day of the market, the scenes from the animated film were screened in Asia for the first time; the invitation to the premiere appeared on the cover of The Hollywood Reporter, and the screening itself was successful and gathered positive feedback from market participants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stolenprincess.com/en/news/text/20-in-asia-the-first-screening-of-the-stolen-princess-takes-place|title=In Asia, The First Screening of The Stolen Princess Takes Place|accessdate=2017-05-29}}</ref> In early April, Cannes hosted MIPTV (Marché International des Programmes de Télévision), a major European market of audiovisual content. The stand of Ukrainian delegation presented, among others, ''The Stolen Princess'' film.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stolenprincess.com/en/news/text/21-filmua-group-presented-the-stolen-princess-animation-project-at-miptv-in-cannes|title=FILM.UA Group Presented The Stolen Princess Animation Project at MIPTV in Cannes|language=|work=The Stolen Princess|publisher=Official site of the project|accessdate=2017-04-04}}</ref> On May 19 and 23, 2017 the biggest film market Marche du Film under the aegis of the 70th [[Cannes International Film Festival]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stolenprincess.com/en/news/text/25-ukrainian-animation-features-in-cannes-the-stolen-princess-and-mavka-the-forest-song-at-marche-du-film|title=Ukrainian Animation Features in Cannes: The Stolen Princess and Mavka. The Forest Song at Marche du Film|publisher=The official site of the film "The Stolen Princess"|accessdate=2017-05-31}}</ref> held market screenings of ''The Stolen Princess'', which enjoyed considerable success: the project gathered countless positive reviews, and negotiations on rights sales for the new territories began.
Immediately after Ukrainian release, the theatrical release took place in [[Romania]] (March 16) and Turkey (March 23). During the first Romanian weekend, Ukrainian animated feature film collected $165,066 in the box office<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stolenprincess.com/en/news/text/54-in-the-first-weekend-of-international-release-the-stolen-princess-collects-an-impressive-box-office-in-romania|title=In the First Weekend of International Release, The Stolen Princess Collects an Impressive Box Office in Romania|publisher=The official site of the film "The Stolen Princess"|accessdate=2018-03-21}}</ref> and placed second after American blockbuster [[Lara Croft]]: [[Tomb Raider]] (Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer). It is interesting to compare the film with the main animated releases of 2017–2018 from Hollywood majors such as [[Disney Pixar]], [[DreamWorks Animation]], and [[Blue Sky Studios]], which also took place in Romania: the box office of Ukrainian Princess during the first weekend exceeded those of [[Coco (2017 film)|Coco]], [[Ferdinand the Bull]], and Baby Boss, ceding only to the third movie of Cars franchise. The premiere box office of the Ukrainian film places it third among animated releases in Turkey in 2018.
As of April 13, ''The Stolen Princess'' is now shown in the cinemas of [[Ukraine]], [[Romania]], [[Turkey]], [[Croatia]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Egypt]], [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Kuwait]], [[Lebanon]], [[Jordan]], [[Qatar]], [[Oman]] and [[Bahrain]]. In total, the rights to the animated film screening have been sold to more than 50 countries, including France, Germany, countries of the Middle East, Southern Africa, Asia, and Latin America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stolenprincess.com/en/news/text/65-ukradena-princeza-and-otkradnatata-printsesa-ukrainian-cartoon-just-released-in-croatia-bosnia-and-hertzegovina-and-bulgaria|title="Ukradena princeza" and "Откраднатата принцеса": Ukrainian animated feature film just released in Croatia, Bosnia and Hertzegovina, and Bulgaria|publisher=The official site of the film "The Stolen Princess"|accessdate=2018-04-06}}</ref> In November 2018 Ukrainian media reported that the film had been shown in more than 40 countries with more than half a million viewers.<ref name="234385princess"/> In January 2019 the film will become the first Ukrainian film to be commercially released to cinemas in China.<ref name="234385princess">{{uk icon}} [https://life.pravda.com.ua/culture/2018/11/29/234385/ "The kidnapped princess" will become the first Ukrainian film to be shown in cinemas of China], [[Ukrayinska Pravda|''Life'']] (29 November 2018)</ref>
===Distribution in Ukraine=== [[File:2018 Ukraine Stamp 02.jpg|thumb|[[Postage stamp]]s of [[Ukrposhta|Ukraine]], 2018]] In late December 2016 it was announced that the film will change its title from Ruslan and Lyudmila to ''The Stolen Princess'' for its Ukrainian release as well (before that, in February 2016 the film producers already informed that they will use ''The Stolen Princess'', not Ruslan and Lyudmila as the title for international distribution). In October 2017 it became known that film producers changed the title of the film for Ukrainian release again, to ''The Stolen Princess: Ruslan and Lyudmila''. The date of Ukrainian release, March 7, 2018, also became known. On December 15, 2015, in the framework of winter film market of Odessa International Film Festival Novyi TV channel acquired the rights to TV broadcast of the film. According to the deal, the TV premiere of the film is scheduled in six months after the start of its theatrical release.
==Soundtrack==
The theme song of the film Do zirok (To the Stars) was performed by [[Vremya i Steklo]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://film.ua/uk/news/1891|title=PREMIER OF THE CLIP! "Time and Glass" performed the main song of the animated feature film "The Stolen Princess: Ruslan and Lyudmila" in Ukrainian}}</ref> band. On February 14, a music video for the song was presented. The author of the Ukrainian lyrics is Oleksandra Ruban, the arrangement to the song was made by Milos Jelic, keyboard player in [[Okean Elzy]] band, and the instrumental part was performed by the musicians of Kyiv Virtuosos orchestra. {{tracklist | collapsed = | headline = List of track | extra_column = | total_length =
| all_writing = | all_lyrics = | all_music = | writing_credits = | lyrics_credits = | music_credits =
| title1 = Do zirok | note1 = [[Vremya i Steklo]] | lyrics1 = Oleksandra Ruban | music1 = Rafael Lake, Aaron Levy | length1 = 3:13
| title2 = Ty Lyubov Moya | note2 = [[Jamala]] | lyrics2 = Oleksandra Ruban | music2 = Robbie Nevil | length2 = 4:05
}}
The final song in the end credits to the feature film, Ty Lyubov Moya (You’re My Love), was performed by [[Jamala]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BfqB6xpnPFW/?taken-by=thestolenprincessfilm|title=The Stolen Princess в Instagram: "The animation film team # The Stolen Princess has a musical surprise for you 😊 The final film song is performed by Jamal(@jamalajaaa)!…»|website=Instagram|language=uk|accessdate=2018-03-07}}</ref>
==Box office==
During the first weekend in Ukraine, the film collected 21 million UAH ($0.8 million) in its box office. During five weekends, the film collected 35,857,041 UAH and hit a record among films produced in Ukraine.<ref name="boxoffice_sp">{{cite web|url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?id=_fSTOLENPRINCESSRU01&country=UA&wk=2018W11&id=_fSTOLENPRINCESSRU01&p=.htm |title= "Stolen Princess: Ruslan and Lyudmyla|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo|BOM]]}}</ref>
==Reviews==
The film got mixed reviews. The audience noted the lack of Ukrainian flavor and blind copying of Hollywood standards, inappropriate references to current realia, and lack of charisma among certain characters. However, the reviewers have also praised high animation standards, clever jokes, and the animated feature film appealing to topics of interest to both adults and children.<ref name = "ufd"/>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Transporter'' (franchise)}} {{More citations needed|date=June 2009}} {{Infobox media franchise |title=''Transporter'' |caption= DVD set containing the first three films |image= Transporter Trilogy cover.jpg |imagesize= |origin= |creator=[[Luc Besson]]
[[Robert Mark Kamen]] |films={{plainlist| *''[[The Transporter]]'' (2002) *''[[Transporter 2]]'' (2005) *''[[Transporter 3]]'' (2008) *''[[The Transporter Refueled]]'' (2015) }} |tv=''[[Transporter: The Series]]'' (2012–2014) |atv= |games= |vgs= |books= |comics= |soundtracks= {{plainlist| *[[The Transporter#Soundtrack|''The Transporter'']] (score) *[[Transporter 2#Soundtrack|''Transporter 2'']] *''Transporter 3'' }} |music= }} '''''Transporter''''' (French: '''''Le Transporteur''''') is an English-language French [[action film]] franchise, comprising four films released between 2002 and 2015, and a television series. [[Jason Statham]] plays Frank Martin in the first three movies, a professional freelance courier driver for hire. Statham himself is an accomplished [[martial artist]], allowing him to do all the combat scenes involving Frank Martin himself. This permits the films' signature Hong Kong-style fight scenes, choreographed by [[Corey Yuen]]. [[Chris Vance (actor)|Chris Vance]] portrays Frank Martin in the [[Transporter: The Series|television series]] and [[Ed Skrein]] portrays Frank Martin in the [[The Transporter Refueled|fourth film]], a [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]]. ==Films== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width=99% |- !
